ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES  
CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

We have a request from Agent Ostrander, Battleford Agency, for the expenditure of $10.00 to build a cupboard at the Thunderchild Indian Day School to store material and equipment for the Thunderchild Homemakers' Club.

Mrs. Ross, the teacher at this school, finds herself handicapped for storage facilities and this would certainly be a Godsend to her if this assistance could be given.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
May 18, 1943.

Mr. M. Christianson, Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg., Searth & Victoria, Regina,
Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 12th
instant, the Department approves an expenditure
of $10.00 for the erection of a cupboard at the
Thunderchild Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, July 8, 1943.

Mr. J.F.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

With reference to requisition dated the 30th ultimo, you may purchase the following articles for use at the Thunderchild Indian Day School:

- 12 pkgs. chloride of lime,
- 6 tins Gillett's Lye,
- 3 doz. bars laundry soap,
- 1 soup kettle,
- 4 brooms,
- 6 spools thread
- 2 pkgs. needles,

16 yds. hand towelling,
6 pkgs. Rinso,
2 doz. bars Lifebuoy Soap,
1 wash board,
20 yds. Print,
20 # Flannelette,
1 scrubbing brush.

The following supplies may also be purchased for midday meal purposes:

- 1 lb. black pepper
- 100 # Rice
- 10 # Cocoa
- 2 cases Milk

60 lbs. rolled oats
100 # Beans
50 # Macaroni

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Battleford, Sask.
August 6th, 1943.

Department of Mines and Resources, Indian Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

Will you please grant authority to have the inside walls of the Thunderchild Indian Day School white washed, and repairs to the roof? Material will cost approximately $25.00 and labour $25.00.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
August 13, 1943.

EX'D

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant, you may expend an amount of $60.00 for material and labour for whitewashing the walls of the Thunderchild Day School and repairing the roof.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
IN ACCOUNT WITH

M. A. HOLLIDAY
HARDWARE, TINSMITHING, PLUMBING AND HEATING
RADIOS, CHINA AND SILVERWARE

Ottawa, March 8, 1945.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, Indian Agent, Battleford, Sask.

The report of Inspector C. Bowes regarding his inspection of the Thunderchild Indian Day School has just reached this office. The following is an extract from the report:

"The interior of the school is dark and needs extensive remodelling. It is doubtful if the building is worth renovating. There is not sufficient blackboard space. The blackboard is too high for the younger pupils."

There will be no funds available in the coming year's appropriation for the erection of a new school at this point. However, we could supply funds for a reasonable amount of repairs, if you consider such action advisable. Please let me have your comments.

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

Mr. Warden has asked me to look over the plans of the proposed school for Thundershild Indian Reserve and suggest a method of heating this building by use of a gravity warm air system.

I am enclosing a plan of such a system, worked out according to the code of the National Warm Air Heating and Air Conditioning Assoc., of which I am an associated member.

This will give you an idea of the feasibility of such a plan.

The warm air pipes for the basement rooms would probably be slightly more effective if taken off the top of the furnace bonnet, with an enlarged take off for each, while the risers or rather leader pipes to the upstairs risers should be taken off the sloping sides of the bonnet.

Warm air floor registers on the first floor class rooms and hall and high wall registers or grills in the basement rooms and hall would tend to equalize better the outlet of the warm air, but floor registers are undesirable in public buildings in particular, so I have high wall registers in all rooms and have reduced the size of the 1st floor risers accordingly.

I have included a thermo-draft control in the smoke stacks as a safety device and if still obtainable I would strongly recommend thermostatic control of the furnace draft and check dampers. These are spring operated and require no electric current and have proved satisfactory in the past.

Regularity and efficiency in the care of firing operations has a most decided effect on the results obtained from hand fired furnaces.

The price for this complete installation, left ready to fire, would be $1480.00, Fourteen Hundred and Eighty Dollars, providing it can be done while the roads and weather permit.

After you have examined the enclosed plan, please return all material to me as soon as possible as I have only one copy.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) H. C. Dunfield.

We have received your letters of September 1st and September 3rd in connection with the proposed erection of a two room school on the Thunderchild Reserve.

It is noted that Olaf Lidfors is prepared to erect the building according to plan submitted to him at a cost of $19,650.00 and that he will use the heating plant sold by H.C. Dunfield & Co., as outlined in your letter of the first instant.

We have reviewed the floor plan and the quotation of Dunfield & Co. The Department does not approve cold air ducts below the basement floor. The drop in temperature will be so great that we fear it will impair the efficiency of the furnace. Besides, there is a danger that rubbish may collect in them.

We realize that the cold air from the basement will be difficult to install above the floor. We think that this can be done along the wall on the floor. In no case should the cold air from the classrooms pass under the basement floor.

In addition, the cold air in the classrooms must not draw from below the hot air, but from the other end of the room. This will require a duct along the beam on the ceiling and will require more material and possibly cost slightly more.
Before considering Mr. Lidfor's tender, we would like to know if the suggestions that we have made above will increase the amount of the tender.

As soon as we receive your reply, the matter will be submitted to the Minister for approval.

Bernard F. Neary

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th Sept. with a copy of Mr. Neary's letter of the 13th, re heating of the proposed Thunderchild Reserve School.

For your own information I would like to say that two years ago I installed a heating system in a school of four rooms, 2 upstairs and 2 in the basement.

The only feasible method of returning the air from the basement rooms to the furnace was through sub floor ducts, which I used. The installation is quite satisfactory.

In the early days of warm air heating this was general practice, particularly when all supply air was brought in from outside. In the colder climates heating outside air proved expensive, less outside air was introduced and more air from the building was recirculated, still using sub floor returns to a large extent, but as the indoor air recirculated, is almost always from floors above the furnace room, it was found much cheaper to drop the returns alongside of the furnace and enter the casing above the floor level.

A warm air heating system is very feasible and will give good results at efficiencies much below what might be considered par, if the basic factors are kept in balance. For instance heat radiated from the firepot will enter the cold air shoe, if it is too high on the casing, raise the temperature of the return air and lower the efficiency of the circulating system somewhat. This need not be but it could be serious if overdone.

Heat flows through practically all materials where there is a temperature differential between the two sides of the barrier, thus heat is flowing constantly through the basement floor to the ground below, raising its temp. Recent tests in the Research Dept. of the University of Illinois show that for heated basement rooms, the temperature of the ground beneath a concrete floor, laid on the ground, and more than 5 ft. from the outside wall, remains nearly constant and but little colder than the surface temperature of the floor.

Under the above conditions, sub-floor return ducts would, very probably, maintain more even temperature than would ducts in many other places.

The only motive force available, in a gravity warm air system,
to circulate air, is the difference in weight between outgoing and return air. This difference is not great, at best. To obtain the maximum results, resistance to the easy flow of air should be reduced to the minimum. Air will flow more easily through the room area than it will through a duct. Therefore, I use the shortest possible way for both leader pipes and return air ducts.

In the case in question the return air can be brought from the upper class rooms to the furnace room and dropped down alongside the furnace to enter the casing at floor level.

The only way in which air can be returned from the basement rooms to the furnace is by a duct on top of the furnace room floor, which would be a constant source of irritation, or by using a sub floor return, which is thoroughly practicable and efficient.

I would like to have a decision on this point also, whether coal or wood is to be the main fuel. Large wood-burning furnaces are in very short supply, particularly those that may be converted from wood burners to coal burners.

Regarding the placement of cold air registers on the opposite side of the room to inlet register

Theoretically this is correct, on the warm air side, circulation effect takes a heating due to the added resistance in length of run and more bends. In fan heating or forced air work this added resistance can be easily estimated and taken care of but in gravity systems you start with a given maximum motive force. It cannot be increased. It can only be conserved.

I find that I have run well into a discourse on a heating, which probably will be of value to me only, in restating for my own benefits, values that I might otherwise lose sight of.

What I really started out to say was:

(1) Is coal or wood to be the main fuel?
(2) Will sub floor return ducts from basement rooms be acceptable?

Please let me know as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) H. C. Dunfield
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a two-room Indian day school on the Thunderchild Indian Reserve, Battleford Agency, in the Province of Saskatchewan;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Thunderchild Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building contractor, namely, Mr. Olaf Lidforss, of Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, has agreed to undertake the erection of a two-room school immediately at a price of $19,650.00.

THAT it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted for the erection of this building as outlined above, this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children of the Thunderchild Reserve.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Thunderchild Indian Day School.

Included in our Estimates for 1948-49 is the sum of $14,000.00 for the erection of a one-room Indian Day School and attached teacher's residence on the Thunderchild Indian Reserve, Battleford Agency, Saskatchewan. When our Educational Survey Officer visited this reserve in the late spring, he found that the number of children enrolled at the present school or attending residential schools was such that we should build a two-room and not a one-room school, as previously planned.

He found that the present teacherage was in good condition but that the school building was in need of immediate replacement. Therefore, we have already had approved by the Minister, the sum necessary to build an addition to the present teacherage so that it will accommodate both teachers required.

Our Regional Supervisor for Saskatchewan has now been able to obtain a satisfactory tender for the erection of a two-room school (without teachers' residence). Our experience elsewhere with the building of similar schools has been such that we feel it is indeed a reasonable tender and one which we can recommend for acceptance. You will note that it is submitted by Olof Lidfors of Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, who has also submitted a tender for the erection of a one-room day school and attached residence on the Meadow Lake Reserve. This latter tender is now before the Governor General in Council for consideration. Mr. Ostrander has advised as follows concerning having Mr. Lidfors erect both these schools:

"I have to say that Mr. Lidfors intends to have both buildings under erection at the same time, if both are..."
authorized, and he will personally supervise the construction of both buildings.

"Certainly I am anxious to have the Meadow Lake Indian Day School erected first for certain well known reasons, but both buildings require a considerable amount of excavation and concrete work which must be done before severely cold weather, if done at all during the fiscal year.

"It is my recommendation that this part of the work be completed on both buildings at the earliest possible date, after which I would have Mr. Lidfora proceed with the completion of the Meadow Lake school with as many men as possible until it is ready for occupancy. Completion of the Thunderchild school would proceed after the Meadow Lake school."

I would recommend that the attached submission to Council be approved and forwarded for necessary action.

Acting Director.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 25th September, 1948, from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a two-room Indian day school on the Thunderchild Indian Reserve, Battleford Agency, in the Province of Saskatchewan;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Thunderchild Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides, in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building contractor, namely, Mr. Olof Lidforss, of Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, has agreed to undertake the erection of a two-room school immediately at a price of $19,550.00;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into a contract with Mr. Olof Lidforss for the erection of the building as outlined above, this being the most suitable arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried on to completion in order to provide educational facilities for the Indian children of the Thunderchild Reserve.

The Honourable the Minister of Mines and Resources. Clerk of the Privy Council

THIS AGREEMENT made (in triplicate) the thirtieth day of October in the year Nineteen Hundred and Forty Eight A.D.

BETWEEN

Mr. Olof Lidforss, Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan,

hereinafter called "The Contractor", of the first part;

AND His Majesty the King, represented by the Minister of Mines and Resources of Canada, hereinafter called "The Minister", of the second part,

WHEREAS the party of the first part, for the consideration hereinafter mentioned, has agreed with the party of the second part, to do, furnish and perform the work, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in the manner hereafter described, in connection with the work or works;

NOW THIS INDENTURE WITNESSETH that the said parties hereto, hereby covenant, promise and agree, each with the other as follows:

ARTICLE I: The covenants, clauses, provisos and conditions of the Tender Form, General Instructions to Bidders, and Specifications, (embracing the General Conditions, Labour Conditions, General Specifications and Trade Specifications) together with the drawings and such additional detail drawings, shop drawings and instructions, as may from time to time be furnished, shall be as fully part of this Agreement as if attached hereto, or herein repeated, and should the Contractor or Minister fail to sign them, they shall nevertheless be binding on both parties.
ARTICLE II: The Contractor undertakes and agrees:

(a) to do, furnish and perform, the works, materials, matters and things required to be done, furnished and performed, in connection with the following work or works namely,—

The construction of a two-room school to be known as the Thunderchild Indian Day School, as per the following contract:

(b) to complete substantially, and to the satisfaction of the Minister, all the work, on or before the date or dates following, viz:—

the thirty-first day of July Nineteen Hundred and Forty Nine A.D.

(c) Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

ARTICLE III: The Minister undertakes and agrees, in consideration of the premises, and subject to the performance and observation on the part of the Contractor, of all covenants, provisos and conditions in the Specifications contained:
(a) To pay the Contractor in current funds, for the performance of the contract, Nineteen Thousand, Six Hundred and Fifty Dollars subject to additions and deductions as provided for in the Specifications governing the work.

(b) To make progress payments on account thereof, as provided for in the Specifications, equal to ninety per cent (90%) of the value, proportionate to the amount of the Contract, of labour and materials incorporated into the work, as estimated by the Engineer, less the aggregate of previous payments.

(c) On completion of the entire work, and on full performance of the covenants and clauses of the Specifications, to make full payment of the balance due under the Contract, as set out in the Specifications.

ARTICLE IV: The Contractor and the Minister for themselves, their successors, executors, administrators and assigns, hereby undertake and agree, to the full performance of the covenants contained herein.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that the Indians of White Bears Band have for a long time past been anxious that a day-school be opened for their children on the reserve, and when the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs visited the Reserve a short time ago, the Indians asked him to give them the school, and he promised them that they should have one.

There are about twenty children of school age on the reserve, but most of them are not fit to be sent to an Industrial School owing to their being in very poor health; most of them are suffering from scrofula, and other kindred diseases; some are strong and healthy but their parents will not let them be sent to an Industrial School.

It would be a good thing if the school could be opened this winter - and I think that after these children get used to a day school, it will be easier to persuade their parents to have them sent

The Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.
to some Industrial Institution.

There is a building on the reserve that could be used for a school house.

Respectfully submitted,

H.R. Halpin.

Sir,

I have much pleasure in acknowledging the receipt of your letter No. 178701/1.

I appreciate highly your kind expression regarding the standing of the White Bear School. For the monetary recognition of our success, I also thank you.

I am pleased to send you the following report of our school work, and also of work among the Indians on the Reserve.

Steady progress has been made in the school, especially during the last year. All the children of school are on the Reserve, except three, are enrolled. The diseased condition of these three prevents their admission to the school at present. The average daily attendance for the present quarter is 16.37.

Owing to extremely cold weather during the first month of the term the attendance was not very high but since the first of February the average is over 19.

A pleasing feature is the improvement in punctuality, there being now only two or three families from which children come late to school. But even these cases are improving.

In cleanliness and neatness in appearance also there is a very marked improvement. These facts alone indicate an improvement in the home atmosphere. But in improved deportment and in attention to work, in cheerful obedience and in the happy confidence of even the youngest pupil, we read the place the school holds in the opinion of the parents.

The school atmosphere is very evidently effecting the home life of the Indians and it is my very earnest desire to the
The Department of Indian Affairs,

best of my ability to further the purpose of the Department in placing this school here, that it may be a lasting benefit to the Indian people.

I do not think the present condition of our school is the result of any special method of work. I think it is rather the result of a happy combination of circumstances.

When we remember how slowly the Indian mind adopts new ideas, we are not surprised that the very earnest efforts of past years are only now being felt. But that these efforts have helped to bring about our present condition, I am sure.

Again, we have been provided with a comfortable, commodious school building; we are supplied with all necessary apparatus for carrying on our work comfortably; we have a wise law requiring the Indian parents to place their children under instruction, and we have an Indian Agent who is firm, yet kind and tactful, in carrying out the law.

In the school room I have simply done the part of a teacher.

The discipline is good, yet it is maintained with very little effort, when once the relative positions of teacher, pupils and parents are recognized. There is careful attention to detail. Every child is expected to do his best, and only the best is taken, though it may be far below the standard of perfection. The interest of the pupils is readily gained by being interested in whatever interests them, and where the confidence of the children is given, the parents hearts soon follow.

By choosing lessons within the comprehension of the children, their interest in the school work is maintained and they work with a will. There is nothing more than this.

Of punishments there is nothing more than placing a naughty child in a corner of the room, and letting him feel that he has disgraced himself. Only on two or three occasions in the three years that I have been in charge of this school have I needed to use corporal punishment, and then one clap
The Department of Indian Affairs.

was sufficient. But both parents and children know that discipline will be maintained at any costs.

There are very few rewards in the way of prizes. Occasionally a small prize is offered for the highest attendance in the quarter, but it is not sufficient to induce a child to come to school if he or his parents wish to go on a visit somewhere. The children are given a cup of tea with their biscuit at noon. It gives the school a homely feeling and may help a little. Then when leaving school in the evening any hungry child may have another biscuit to eat as he runs home.

I have carefully avoided any course which would lead the parents to think that I was receiving benefit by the children being in school and would tolerate any caprice on their part or on the part of their children, rather than lose them. And further, I have put as much responsibility on the parents themselves as possible.

In the case of an incorrigible girl, I dismissed her from the school. When the father found that her persistent disobedience brought her punishment, he at once undertook disciplining his other children who were in the school. The matter spread among the Indians and there was an awakening as to their duty of teaching their children obedience.

The parents were then asked to supply firewood free of cost for the school. Only once have I needed to close the school for want of wood. The school was closed three days but I did not reopen until the wood was brought. This winter we went a step farther. The Assiniboine lived so far from the school as to make regular attendance impossible for their children. We suggested that the parents go together, bring logs and build a house near the school-house, and that all the Assiniboine children be placed in charge of an Indian and his wife. They promptly agreed to the proposal and the children have been comfortably in school without any risk of frost-bites.

I think that by placing some responsibility upon the parents in this way, their interest has been aroused, the school has become a very real thing to them and it is slowly but surely...
The Department of Indian Affairs.

helping them upward.

My work among the Indians on the reserve is chiefly helping to care for the sick. To see that the doctor's directions are carried out. Helping to induce the women to keep their homes and children clean. Visiting the school children in their homes so as to keep in touch with them and their parents.

There is a discouragingly large amount of work to be done on the Reserve. I can touch only the outside of it. My visits can be made only on Saturdays or after four o'clock on school days.

But we have been able to accomplish something. There is more willingness to use civilized methods in treating diseases and there are some genuine efforts to keep houses and children clean.

Some of the women are becoming quite clever at making clothes for their children from cast-off clothing of older people, and they very willingly make up clothing that I cut and send to them for the school children.

A very earnest effort is being made to correct old and harmful practices as the marriage of very young girls, practically children; the putting away of one wife and taking another or the taking of two at once and other domestic irregularities. Some success has attended the efforts in these respects. But something more than "moral suasion" is necessary. Here again the law is firmly administered and there is very good reason to believe that as the Indian men and women are taught to respect their marriage relations, they will rise in self respect and their homes will improve.

I would like to express to you my gratitude for the help and sympathy I receive in my work from the Agency Staff. In every way possible my little efforts are furthered by Agent, Farmer, Clerk and Doctor. Under these circumstances we may hope for progress in this band of Indians.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 24th April No. 178701 regarding lodging arrangements for the Assiniboine children, and its maintenance, I beg to say:

(1) The building, 18 ft x 15 ft, is of logs, with an earth roof. There are two windows, one of four 12 in. x 14 in. lights, towards the south. The other, of two 12 x 14 lights, is towards the west. There is a good lumber floor, and the building is lime washed within and without.

One end of the building is occupied by the beds of the children, which are made similar to berths in a steamer. There are three of these, and they are separated from the living room.
by a cotton curtain run on a stout wire. A bedstead is in the outer room, which is used by the Indian and his wife.

The berths are supplied with ticks filled with straw, which is renewed when necessary. The ticking was supplied by the Indian Department through the Indian Agent's Corp., as was also the material for the curtains. A blanket for each bed was also loaned from the store-house. The quilts, sheets and pillows, cases and towels were supplied by the mission. The parents supplied feather pillows.

The living-room is furnished with a good strong table and two strong benches. There is a small cooking-stone (the property of the Indians) and during the winter a box-stove for keeping fire at night was provided by the mission store-house.

The Indians' parents bring the firewood, and they take the children's clothes to wash on Saturdays.
The Indians and his wife, and the children attending the school from this house, get rations from the store house. All the children take the noon meal in the school-house. This meal is either biscuits and tea or biscuits and boiled rice. The biscuits and rice are provided by the Department. The tea and sugar by myself. I also prepare the noon meal. There is nothing paid to the Indian and his wife besides their rations.

They frequently spend the week end among their friends, leaving Saturday noon and returning Sunday evening. But often they find it convenient to remain at this end of the Reserve for several weeks at a time. The parents of the children come for them Friday afternoons and bring them back on Sunday, when they come for service or on Monday morning.

There are six children from this Reserve in the Ju'Apple Industrial School, and one at Regina Industrial School.
Since the removal of the Rev. Mr. Hodges to the charge of the Cecilia Jeffrey School, I have had charge of the Evangelistic work here; and for better convenience in carrying on that work, I moved into the mission house. Up to that time I found a house with the Agent's family and, later, with the Farmer's. The mission house is a comfortable, six-roomed house with mission hall attached.

It is situated about 100 yards from the school house. There is a comfortable little frame stable and a good sized storehouse. I also cultivate the garden. The children's house is about 50 yards from the mission house.

The suggestion to appoint an assistant for this work is most kind. I thank you indeed. I feel that if the right person be sent we will be able to overtake all the work, and in a way that will give good results.
The work might be divided in this way: One take charge of the school and mission. The other have the care of the homes. This would mean a very practical knowledge of housekeeping—of bread making, cooking, washing, sewing, mending, cutting out garments, knitting; nursing the sick under most unfavorable circumstances. Indeed it seems to me a woman must be made especially to be successful in this work. Since our school has filled up I find it almost impossible for me to give the girls the instruction they need in sewing and knitting, in darnimg & mending their clothes. An assistant could help me out much in these matters.

We are having this year a small piece of ground broken near the school house for a garden for the children. We thought of allowing the children to take home the produce.
of their little plot; but under the assistants' care the children could enjoy their vegetables at the noon meal. A bowl of warm vegetable soup at noon with their biscuit would certainly be appreciated, and the fact that they had raised these vegetables themselves would give it just the flavor that they need.

I thank you indeed, for your sympathy in our work here, and I trust that the future may show good results among these people.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

E. Way Armstrong

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter above quoted asking me if I could add anything by way of a supplement to my report on White Bear's Bay school, made in December last.

At the time of my inspection of the Moose Mountain Agency in August last, Miss Armstrong, the Principal, was away for her holidays, and the school was closed; consequently I was unable to make any report. I was able, however, to learn from the Agent that the attendance was good and that Miss Armstrong was still doing good work; that a number of children from the far end of the reserve, four or five miles distant, were living in a shack in charge of an Indian woman, and attended school regularly all winter. I have no doubt the Agent has reported on this matter.

I note that the Department has under consideration the appointment of an assistant to Miss Armstrong. At the time of my last inspection of this little school I noticed a decided improvement.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
improvement in the children over the previous inspections, in fact, I firmly believe that Miss Armstrong has done more in the way of advancing the children in the two years that she has been in charge of the school, than was done during all the previous years the school has been in existence, which proves conclusively that she is in the right place and understands Indian work. The greatest obstacles with which this school has to contend are the poor home surroundings of these children and the example of indolence that is always before them. The Indians of the Moose Mountain Agency are, without doubt, the poorest lot of Indians in this Inspectorate. They are lazy and very dirty and there is very little to show that they have been instructed for years. I do not know that I can attribute this state of affairs entirely to the Indians themselves, as the supervision that this Agency has had in the last ten years is not what I would call good. If a vigorous and energetic policy were pursued at this Agency there would be some results, I am sure, for after all, the Indians here are not so different to the Indians of the other reserves throughout the Inspectorate, if they were managed properly.

I am not quite sure of the nature of the services
that would be expected from an assistant for Miss Armstrong. If it is to take some of Miss Armstrong's school work so that she would have time to go about and visit the Indians and instruct them in the habits of cleanliness, give them some attention when they are sick, keep an eye on those children who have passed through school, etc. I would strongly advise the appointment of an assistant.

Miss Armstrong has had an assistant in the past, but from what I could see she has been more of a housekeeper in Miss Armstrong's house. This is not the kind of assistance that is required. I do not think it would be advisable for Miss Armstrong to give up the class-room work entirely. She has been successful in this work and should give as much time to it as possible.

The Department should insist on a change in these Indians' methods of farming living and all depends on proper instruction given by its officers.

Ottawa, November 30th, 1909.

Madam,

The Department is advised by Rev. Dr. Mackay that the Western Committee of the Presbyterian Church has at last been successful in securing the services of a trained nurse to assist you in your work on the White Bear Reserve. The question of the division of the work between you is being taken up with Dr. Mackay and in reference to this you will be further advised at a later date.

Dr. Mackay in his letter to the Department refers to the fact that the lodging annex for the children who live at some distance from the school is in use, and the Department would like to impress upon you the necessity of care to avoid over-crowding. This has proved one of the most detrimental features in the case of regular boarding schools, and the Department trusts that the building in use on the White Bear reserve provides plenty of accommodation for the number in residence and that every effort is made to keep it thoroughly ventilated.

The Department would also be glad to know if anything could be done to assist in providing a more varied mid-day meal for the children, and it would be willing to have issued from the Agency store-house a limited supply of soup meat, rice, salt, tea, beans, bacon and biscuits.

The Department trusts that the appointment of this nurse will relieve you and that you will meet with even a larger measure of success in future in your work on this reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Miss E. May Armstrong,
Teacher,
White Bear Indian Day School,
Carlyle, Sask.

Sir,

On the occasion of my last visit to the Moose Mountain Indian reserve on the 23rd of the present month, I was surprised to learn that Miss Smithson had been appointed to the position of nurse on the reserve to assist Miss Armstrong, the present teacher of the Day school. On making enquiry from both the agent and Miss Armstrong, I learned that neither of them have had any instructions regarding this nurse's duties, other than that the church authorities in Toronto told Miss Armstrong to get someone to assist her on the reserve and that she would be paid a salary of $25.00 per month by the Department. When I heard this I felt sure there must be some mistake, and that the Department had not sanctioned the appointment, that Miss Armstrong's authority to engage a nurse was premature, as I felt that the Agent would have been written to regarding this woman's duties, and also with regard to placing her name on the pay list.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa
I knew that the Department had under consideration the appointment of an assistant to Miss Armstrong, as they had written to me for suggestions as to the assistant's duties, and on the 4th of October I wrote at length advising the appointment, but pointed out quite plainly what the duties of an assistant paid by the Department should be, and I took particular care to emphasize the fact that she was to give all her time to the Indians and not to act as housekeeper in Miss Armstrong's home. I am told that since Miss Smithson came she has spent three afternoons a week visiting Indians. My opinion is that she should spend nearly all her time with the Indians. The work is to be done, and to do it requires more than three afternoons a week.

Of course I feel rather reluctant about giving any instructions or advice, as I did not know whether the young woman was there with the Department's authority, however, I did tell her that I had no instructions or advice of her appointment and that anything I did tell her was given as my own views and not official and that her instructions would come from Ottawa. If it should happen that Miss Smithson is there with the Department's knowledge, I think it would be safe to advise her to work out on the lines laid down.
down by me, which were as follows:

Visit all the Indians regularly at their homes; see that their houses were whitewashed at least twice during the winter; instruct them almost daily in the way they should keep their houses and premises surrounding them, personally see that all the children attending school take a bath at the school at least once a week, on Saturday or some other other convenient day. She should, when the doctor visits the reserve take instructions regarding the treatment to be given Indians, and see that they are carried out. She should also dispense the medicines used on the reserve and look after them.

The position is one in which a great deal of good can be done if the instructions are carried out; on the other hand if the duties are not defined and the work not checked up little will be accomplished. The work will at times be discouraging, but if the instructions are followed out results will follow.

The Department should insist that the nurse's full time be given to Indians. Housekeeping could take up half the time and it is well to start out with a thorough understanding on this point.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I am in receipt of letter No. 17870/1.

In reference to letter No. 17870/1 of the 6th last I beg to say that we have earnestly endeavoured to carry on the work in the school and on the Reserve along the lines suggested by the Department. Our efforts have been, in some degree, successful.

I have continued the work in the classroom myself except for a day or half day occasionally when business called me away. At such times Miss Smithers
took charge of my work, and I have continued visiting the homes of the children, whenever possible, after school hours, and on Saturdays.

Miss Smithson's mornings have been employed in preparing the noon meal for the school children, and for ourselves; in treating cases of sore eyes, and serious sores which came to her for treatment; in dispensing medicine, and in cutting and preparing work to be done by the mothers or the children.

From 1:30 p.m. to 2:30 p.m. she has taught a class of girls sewing, knitting, mending, darning, and occasionally ironing. The classes go on alternate days.
So that only one class is absent from the school room at once.

After 2:30 p.m., she is generally free to go on the Reserve.

On alternate Friday afternoons, after 2:30, she has taken charge of the girls in scrubbing the school room, and one Thursday afternoon in the month has been spent in disinfecting the children's heads, and Friday morning in washing their heads.

I have still kept charge of the washing of towels and pinafores in the school, but now that the school has become so full of children, and there is more to be washed, it is very distracting to be melting ice and snow, and attending the wash tubs while dictating lessons, and I am hoping to pass this duty over to Miss Smithson also.
This work could be taken one morning in the week.

So far the house-to-house work has been done only incidentally. Very often Indians come for treatment or for food and medicine for ailing ones on the reserve. Thus prevent Miss Smithson going out; and again, some days have been too cold for her to drive alone.

Miss Smithson is hampered in having no means of conveyance of her own. She has either to borrow my pony or take a chance drive other work with either Mr. Cory or Mr. Williams, both of whom are very obliging and helpful. My pony is not always available, but I have never hindered her visits by withholding the pony when required.

Again, no adequate allowance.
has been made for Miss Smithson's maintenance. Since Oct 1st to Dec 31st last I have had $18.75 to cover maintenance.

The Department will pardon me for feeling somewhat dissatisfied.

I have a chore boy at a cost of about $5.00 per month. Part of his duties is waiting on Miss Smithson, and I meet all other expenses in connection with her maintenance, besides having the responsibility of seeing that the purpose for which Miss Smithson was appointed does not fail.

I sincerely thank the Department for their desire to make my work easier, and I hope that such an arrangement may be made that their desire may be realized. At present it is not so.
I would suggest that a small addition be built to the school house, so as to provide a kitchen, pantry, and bathroom, and that the cellar beneath be fireproof, and large enough to hold the soft water tanks and the vegetables which we hope to raise in the school garden this summer.

In this way the mid-day meal may be prepared at the school, the girls assisting in the preparation. Lessons can be given in bread making, the washing, ironing, mending; the sewing and knitting, and the disinfecting and bathing—all could be done with much less loss of time than now.

Let Miss Smithson's salary be sufficient to enable her to pay her board and thus be free to give her undivided attention to her work.
I think in this way she should be able to undertake the work in the house more satisfactorily. This is now being done.

I would again remind the Department that this is an exceedingly difficult part of the work—the results must necessarily be very slow.

The school is in very fine condition. Our enrollment is twenty-eight and our average attendance per week is sometimes twenty-three. The children are in good health and are very happy. No real effort is now required to get or to keep the children in school.

The mid-day meal is thoroughly enjoyed.

I would be very glad to have some dried fruit for them. I think a dish of steamed apples or pears once in the week would be very beneficial, since we have so few.
vegetables. Next year, I hope we will have a good supply of our own raising.

The children are exceptionally orderly.

I eat my own luncheon in the school-room. The girls, in turn, wash the dishes, and sweep the floor. Then tidy themselves and the younger ones for the afternoon work.

They are very happy, and the parents who often visit the school seem quite satisfied that their children are doing well.

There is increasing improvement in the clean and tidy appearance of the children on coming from their homes. They are now begging to be allowed to take their pianoforos home with them so that they may be sure looking very tidy on the way to school.

And mothers are now making their garments for their children. The disinfecting of heads is being
considered a disgrace, and they are making some effort to remove it.

I receive one pound of soap per week from the Agency storehouse. This I divide, as I see is required, on Fridays, so that washing of children's clothes may be done on Saturday.

There is wonderful improvement in the willingness of the parents to have their children receive civilized treatment for sickness. There were two serious eye cases (Accidents) which took weeks of daily treatment. For some days the treatment had to be given hourly. There was no difficulty in getting both children to the mission without their parents. Miss Smithson came out for them in the morning, took them home at night. Both cases are almost well.

Old people come also irregularly and long distances for eye treatment. But both parents and children...
and children were quite content
to let us have our way with them.

I feel that the house in which the
Assiniboine children lodge during
the winter, should be improved.
Two rooms at least, three would
be better, are needed—a living
room, and two sleeping rooms.
A shingle roof also so that
soft water may be available
for keeping the house clean.

Under the present circumstances
the house is fairly well kept.

I apologize for the delay in
answering letter of 12th.

I was endeavouring to give
the matter a fair trial before
reporting results.

I am Sir,

Your obedient servant

E. May Armstrong

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have this morning a letter from Dr. Farquharson discussing a slight difficulty that has arisen in connection with the nurse at Moose Mountain. You will remember that Miss Smithson retired and they have now a Miss Lough in a temporary appointment. The Department contributes $300.00 a year towards her support, to which the Committee added $150.00, making her salary $450.00, and she to pay $75.00, or at most $100.00 a year for board. Miss Armstrong's home is the only place at which a nurse can board in the Mission and the understanding of the Synodical Committee in making this arrangement was that the nurse should share in the housework, otherwise it would be necessary for Miss Armstrong to hire help which would make $2.00 a week too small a figure for board. The question that arises is whether the Department desires an agent supported by them to have any work in addition to Reserve work? Dr. Farquharson asks me to find out how the Department views the situation. Personally I do not think it would interfere with the Reserve work that a young woman should take some share in doing housework, whilst at the same time it would not be desirable to have her so burdened in household cares as to interfere with work upon the Reserve. It is one of these little things that arise and clog the wheels.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Rev. Sir,

As you are aware in the latter part of the year 1909 authority was given for the engagement of an assistant to Miss Armstrong, teacher of the White Bear day school, Moose Mountain Agency, Saskatchewan, and for sometime a Miss Smithson was engaged in the work. She, however, resigned the position in February, last, and was succeeded by Miss Lough, who resigned on July 25th, last. A successor in the person of Miss Innes was evidently appointed, but of this the Department has had no official notification. The vouchers for her salary for the September and December quarters were forwarded to the Department, but, owing to the fact that no notice of this appointment had been made and furthermore that the vouchers were made out on the regular agency forms, instead of on the school forms, payment was made direct to Miss Innes of the sum of $119.36.

This confusion would not have arisen had the Department been informed of the appointment of Miss Innes, as it should have been. It is to be hoped that in future no appointments of this kind will be made without the knowledge and sanction of the Department. Is it your wish that future cheques be sent to the Treasurer of the Presbyterian Church?

School Matters.

The Field Matron and assistant in the school, Miss Innes, is leaving shortly to take up other work, and this is an appointment that I would strongly advise the Department not to fill again. We have tried it now for three years and in my opinion it has been a complete failure and there is nothing to show for it outside of the school and that could have been done by the regular teacher.

Miss Innes is a hard working, conscientious woman, a woman who did a very hard, cold work and who put up with very poor accommodation. Ever since the appointment of the present teacher, she has lived in the kitchen of the school, and the bath tub in the bath room has been her bed, and the bath room is only 6ft, 6 in. by 7 ft. 4, rather poor quarters for her to occupy for 18 months.

In my opinion this will make it absolutely necessary to make a change from a male to a female teacher before the school opens again on the 1st of September.

The Rev. George Anderson of Manor, who has the oversight of the Indian work here for the Presbyterian Church, has urged as strongly as he possibly can upon the church people of Toronto, who have charge of this work, that a change be made as soon as possible, and he also told them of the big mistake that they made in making this appointment and for the sake of the Indians I would like to see a change made, and I would like to see our school made a public school with a female teacher.

Our school has dropped from being one of the best Indian day schools in the province to a very low place, and as long as there is so much dissatisfaction among the parents and scholars, as there is now it is going to be a hard matter to bring it up again.

Mr. Cory of Moose Mountain Reserve tells me that he has great difficulty in keeping the children at school, owing largely to the fact that the school teacher is neglectful of her duties and really incompetent to serve the purpose of teacher in Domestic Science as well as the other necessaries. As you know the school at Moose Mountain has attached to it a kitchen. Since Miss Porter has been there this kitchen has been used altogether as a refuse room and has not been utilized for the purpose for which it has been built. Mr. Cory suggests that an addition be built to the kitchen where a qualified woman teacher hired by the Department and with the authority of the Agent could live, possibly with an Assistant. This Assistant could be utilized during the forenoon of each day to teach the girls attending the school Domestic Science, knitting, darning, cooking, baking, &c., and in the afternoons could spend her time as a sort of matron going
around from house to house visiting the Indian women and showing them the little niceties of housekeeping. At present the teacher is not in any way under the control of the Agent. She is a lady from Illinois and is an appointee of the Presbyterian church, and her salary comes from the Department who virtually have no control over her. As you are aware this is a concrete case which bears out my opinion with regard to the schools as I have expressed it to you in conversation. We ought to have a policy whereby we would be able to run our own schools regardless of any denomination. Run a state school among the Indians just as we have outside of the Reserves, that is a policy that would meet with the approval of every right thinking person in Canada. We have the expenses now of the schools and supposedly have the responsibility, and at the same time we have not a teacher that we hire or can dismiss for inefficiency. We have simply to put up with whatever the various churches choose to give us in the way of teachers no matter whether they are useful or not. This is a matter that I feel very strongly on as you know and would have liked to personally discuss with you. I will be glad to know if you can give this case favorable consideration and change the conditions there for Mr. Cory assures me the utility of the school is not what it should be by any means. If a house were attached as suggested by him to the end of the kitchen the present kitchen would serve for both the house and the school.

Yours with regards,

Dear Mr. Campbell -

I have your letter of the 16th instant, in reference to the Moose Mountain School and shall institute enquiries regarding the work as performed by Miss Porter.

I wish to correct your impression regarding the relations between the churches and the Department in the management of Indian Schools. The only privilege that the church has is to nominate teachers; the Department approves of the appointments and keeps full control. We have power to dismiss these teachers and on occasions have done so; of course we take this action through the church who nominated them and after stating facts have asked them to nominate a new teacher. Carlyle, Sask., June 30, 1914.

Dear Doctor Grant,

Your letter reached me this morning, and I will reply at once.

To-day June 30th is the closing day of my ten-months school term. I have not been absent from my seat a single day during the year. The day I was required to be present I got up to pray at the 8 o'clock service June 17th, being made up the following Saturday. The attendance continued very good until the end, and the school of regularly attending children have made real progress in their literary and industrial work.

I assured the Agent that the wood for the coming year should be cut and allowed to dry out during the summer, and it had been done. So a good supply of wood is ready for the coming year. Also the building arrangements are in good shape, good draughts.
In the school store, and pupils will arrive.

When I came there was no trouble,
could not make a fire until I had the
pupils taken down, cleaned out.

There was not a stick of wood
cut, or any building material.

Not all do I have the school.
The interior of the school is left clean & in
perfect order at close of school June 30th
a good school garden planted by myself
and the pupils.

The Mission buildings are in
good shape inside & out, a supply of wood
while stock is ready for next year, every
foot of tillable ground is planted.
There is a 2 acre field of fine oats,
a large garden of potatoes, peas beans
lettuce, cress, corns and other garden stuff
also flowers and vines. The place looks well.

I have done my work faithfully in the
sight of God, and have nothing to
give you any cause for regret.

Thank you for your unwavering kindness
from first to last. I am sorry to part from you.
However, aside from that and the splendid home furnished by our Church here, there has been no pleasant features whatever here for me. The Indians are steeped in Paganism, Romanism and ignorance. Not one Christian Indian on the Reserve.

The Sabbath is constantly desecrated by the farm instructors who is completely under the thumb of the Agent. The Agent is not a friend of our Church, and unless he can dominate the missionary-teachers & have them other also in the clique, he works against them. Or should I am telling you the plain truth and do so because I am true to our Church & plan I sent in my resignation three months ago, to the Government at Ottawa, to take effect at the close of this year, August 31, 1914. I now repeat it and hereby state that I resign my position as Teacher Three M School, Sask., to take effect August 31, 1914. In the meantime will help things in excellent shape, and be prepared to go.

Wishing you sincerely for all your goodness to me,

Faithfully yours, Sarah Porter.

Sir,

In answer to your letter of Sept 22nd, 1916 No 178701-1 in regard to the moving of the school house on this reserve. I beg to say that I did not recommend it because I did not approve of it being done as it would entail an immense amount of work that the Indians are not in a position to do properly. The situation is this there are five children living east of the school about one mile the rest of the children live from one mile to four west of the school eleven of them live outside of the three mile limit from the school and they are all young children. Now what I would recommend is that an Indian living in the southwest corner of the inhabited part of the reserve be hired to bring the children living west of the school and take them home again at night this would entail a drive of eight miles morning and night but would assure the attendance of all children well enough to come which would be a big item, as you know the winters here are sometimes so severe that it is impossible for young children to walk any distance with safety and if you have to trust to the parents to fetch a and take them you get a very irregular attendance which does not give either the teacher or children a fair show. I would suggest that an Indian be paid each 75¢ a trip for conveying to and from the school day which would be $1.50 a day.

25th, October, 1917.

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Sir,

Your letter, No 178701_1, dated October, 12th, 1917, has been received and in reply would be to say,

It is not unusual in schools to find some pupils who are clever in almost every line, while others have not the like mental capacity.

We have, in our school, several children whom I consider sub-normal; and, on the day of Agent Cory's last visit, these were all present, while the clever children were absent.

Number work was the subject for the hour, and we were introducing number in the abstract. While these dull children—who are quite young—were quite able to deal with concrete numbers, they seemed quite unable to grasp the ideas in the abstract.

I have been giving special attention to this subject this month, and, I think, the children are making as much progress as possible. The bright ones are going ahead quite fast.

One of the older girls does not seem to be able to distinguish between the sounds of letters and words which are similar in sound, hence, her spelling—except as she can remember the place of the word in the list—is very poor. Her reading, also, is poor, because of poor enunciation; but in Domestic Science, she is up-to-the-average.

Another little fellow, who had been one of our brightest pupils, has learned to smoke, with the inevitable result.
One regrets more than I do the poor showing my school seems to have made before the Inspector, and the Agent. On the occasion of Inspector Graham's last visit, in March 10th, 1916, the day was such that I had to keep the children indoors. The Inspector came near four o'clock. We were all exceedingly tired, but I thought, at the time, that some of the pupils gave intelligent answers to the questions asked.

I am well aware that the pupils have not been getting the drill in number-work needed to give them the confidence which prevents diffidence. The reason for this is found in the conditions under which our school is carried on. The children get a dinner at the school. I have no assistant. The girls who were trained under Miss Innis have left school, and the younger girls are inexperienced. I tried to teach them to prepare the noon-meal, and was thus obliged to be out of the class-room quite often. The pupils were left to do seat-work alone. While seat-work has a place in school management, unsupervised seat-work, if largely used, leads to idle, and often vicious, habits. This I tried to bring to the notice of the Department in my Annual Report, and also in the Quarterly Reports.

Another serious handicap in our work is the want of soft water. For almost two years there has been no water supply. In summer, the children were sent almost a quarter of a mile to carry water for cooking purposes, and often returned with only half a pail. For cleaning purposes, both Teacher and pupils carried water from sloughs. In winter snow and ice had to be melted. As this melting had to be done in the class-room, the school was constantly disturbed.

Though the Indian mothers are doing very well in keeping their children clean and tidy, yet there are often matters needing attention, which the parents do not realize. For instance, the Teacher has frequently to cut the boys' hair and this must be done in the class-room. There are
sore eyes to bathe, and sores to dress, and all this takes the teacher's time from the strictly class-room work.

The garden was made by the older children, under the Teacher's direction, while the little ones were again left at seat-work.

Another difficulty faces us now. There is only one boy in school over twelve years of age, and because of a tubercular neck, he is not able to cut much wood. Even now, the boys lose time from their lessons getting wood, but they will be quite unable to cut enough to keep the class-room warm during the winter, not to speak of wood for the kitchen stove.

I have already drawn the attention of the Agent, the Chief, and Indian parents, to the matter, but, so far, without success.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your Obedient Servant,

[Signature]

E.M.A. Ferrie,
Teacher,
White Bear

Sir,

In answer to your letter of November 7, 1917 No 178701/1 about the water supply for the White Bear school. In regard to the lack of soft water this matter has been brought to the attention of the Department several times with no result, and in regard to the drinking water unless the Department is prepared to spend a very considerable sum in digging a well there is not much chance in improving matters. When I went to school in Ontario we carried our drinking water considerably over a quarter of a mile and if we got back with a half a pail of water there was something doing that we were vitally interested in. The only way to supply the school with soft water is to build a frost proof cistern and the drinking water can be supplied by hauling to the school in a barrel which has its drawbacks. I have been paying an Indian to cut and haul ice for that school for several winters now out of my own pocket to try and make things workable but of course it maybe not satisfactory. It will cost anywhere from one hundred to five hundred dollars to dig a well that will give a good supply of water and I do not know of a public school around this part of the country that has a good supply of drinking water in their own grounds.

Dear Sir:

The Indians including the Chief and Council of the White Bear Reserve, Moose Mountain, Sask., have forwarded a Petition to the Department for the purpose of obtaining new regulations in connection with the education of their children and to have a school established at the White Bear Reserve with Teachers, so that their children can go to school on the Reserve instead of having their children sent away from their home at an early age to school at Round Lake, File Hills, or Qu'Appelle. The Indians who have signed the Petition have requested me to write a letter to the Department in furtherance of their interest in having a school established with competent Teachers who can conduct the School with proper discipline for the older boys and girls on the Reserve and who can give the necessary instruction so that the Parents may have their children at home with them on the Reserve. This fall a number of the Indians on the Reserve were strongly opposed to their boys being sent away to one of the schools mentioned above. In some cases they stated their boys were Seventeen years of age, and they wanted them to remain home to work until the threshing was done, and in some cases the Parents were too old to work, and had no other help, and so they wished them to remain at home instead of being sent away to a school off the Reserve at the commencement of the school term. I have given attention to a number of matters during the past twenty years at this point of interest to the Indians, and have rendered them such services; to assist them at any time I was able to
do so, but I have always made it clear to them that I could not in no cases advise or direct them in connection with any matters within the Jurisdiction of Mr. Cory at the Indian Agent on the White Bear Reserve. This is a matter however of Policy, and is one I think should be taken up by the Department in the interest of these Indians. A number of cases have come before me this fall unsought for in connection with the Indians, and they feel very badly about having their children sent away to school off the Reserve, and they wish to keep their children with them, in some cases they related that some of their children who had been sent away to school died there. They do not attach any blame to the authorities for such accidents, but they say they want to keep their children at home and have them educated on the Reserve. I can understand the difficulty in the way of this will be to get a Teacher who can enforce the proper discipline over the older Boys and girls in a school on the Reserve, and also to educate the parents to the necessity of keeping their children at School, if they are educated at a school on their own Reserve. I feel satisfied that it would remove a source of considerable discontent of a number of the Indians on the White Bear Reserve if a School could be established on this Reserve where the children of the Indians could be educated, as the Parents have a dread of sending their children away from home to attend School, and they seem to have a very strong natural love for their children and wish to keep them at home, and at the same time, they say they are anxious to have their children educated, and they wish the authorities to look into this matter and see if some solution cannot be made to establish a school on the Reserve where
their children can attend and receive the necessary education and discipline. On behalf of the Petitioners I wish to add that I believe this is that/a matter of such importance the Department should give early and the necessary consideration to, in the interests of the Indians on this Reserve, and their children, and if possible to find some solution whereby the difficulty mentioned can be overcome, as it is a difficulty that will arise at the commencement of each school term unless some way can be found to establish a school on this Reserve where the children can be educated. WHITE LAKE INDIAN SCHOOL

I visited this school on October 29th. The Reverend G. A. Hackney, B.A., is in charge as teacher. He has a second class interim certificate for Saskatchewan.

Buildings:

I found the school in a very clean and tidy condition. It has been newly painted this summer. Some inexpensive repairs are required to the foundation. It was pointed out to me that the soft water tank under the kitchen required repairs. It is a plank tank with a galvanized iron lining. It is almost impossible to prevent this class of tank from leaking, and in any event it would be a waste of money to endeavour to keep this tank in shape as the building is only inhabited during the daytime. It would freeze up at night and no tank could be kept in proper repair under those conditions. I cannot see, under present conditions, that this tank is required during the winter months. They can carry sufficient water for drinking and washing purposes, and in the summer possibly a small galvanized iron tank to catch rain water would be useful.

The kitchen is not being used. Midday meal is prepared by Mrs. Hackney in her own home, which is quite close to the school. I pointed out to the principal and the Agent how they could repair the foundation without calling in the services of a stone mason. A couple of sacks of cement is all that would be required, and the Farmer or some handy man could do the work.

Enrolment:

There are 19 pupils on the roll, 14 boys and 5 girls. The average attendance for the last quarter was 14.5 and during the month of October the average attendance was 14. There were 10 boys and 5 girls present on the day of my visit. I found them fairly well clad and fairly clean. The pupils were examined in reading and spelling. I found that the junior boys spoke up very well. Those in the senior grades did not speak very distinctly. Mr. Hackney impressed me as being an earnest and capable teacher. It is, however, very difficult to obtain satisfactory progress in a school such as this, situated on a reserve where the home conditions are so unprogressive. Some of the pupils are very tardy in the mornings. I think that possibly if the Agent would take the matter of attendance in hand, this condition might be improved. I pointed out to him that we cannot expect a teacher to be in his classroom during school hours and at the same time out on the reserve chasing delinquent pupils.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that I inspected the White Bear Indian Day School on May 23rd, and beg to submit the following report.

At present there are 17 Indian children enrolled and 4 white children belonging to Mr. Kerr, the teacher. The grades for the Indian children range from I to IV. The work examined was fair. The reading, I considered, showed a marked improvement since my last inspection. The children appeared fairly clean.

The classroom was tidy and clean, except the washbasins and bench on which the basins are kept for use. I noticed these children did not wash before lunch and in mentioning it to Mr. Kerr, he said it would take too much time. I explained that I considered this part of the school training. These children need training in hygiene, perhaps more than anything else, and are receiving practically none.

The soup for the noon-day meal is made by Mrs. Kerr in her home and brought over and served to the children, along with biscuits. The dishes are then returned and attended to by Mrs. Kerr.

I might add this school is provided with a nice kitchen supplied with a stove and table. Two rooms adjoin it, one is supplied with a large white sink for dishwashing and also a pump for soft water. The other
Department as these rooms are only used for storage and are not even kept clean and tidy.

The discipline was good, and the children appeared interested in their work. Eleven were present the day I inspected the school. In looking back over the register, I found the attendance to average about 13. Colds and sickness of various kinds appeared to be the cause for lack of attendance.

The school has received some repairs since my last visit. The windows were closed on the children's right and all the light now comes in over their left shoulder. This repair work has not yet been painted.

The fence about the school is in a disgraceful condition. Many of the posts have rotted off and the wire is badly bent and twisted. This fence should be re-built and the yard enlarged. At present the school is only fenced on two sides, the remaining two have no protection and the windows are liable to be broken at any time by stray horses. If new material were used it would require about 40 cedar posts and 40 rods of wire. By using some of the old wire, 30 rods of new wire would be sufficient.

Sir:

The Department has received the report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his recent visit to the White Bear Indian Day School. I have to request that you will draw to the attention of the teacher the following remarks of the Inspector:

He states that while the classroom was tidy and clean, the wash basins and the bench upon which they are kept were not in a cleanly condition; further, that the teacher did not have the children wash before lunch. The teacher should insist upon cleanliness of person among the pupils, and, as there are facilities provided for the purpose, he should see that the children wash up before partaking of lunch.

He further states that the soup for the noonday meal is made by Mrs. Kerr in her home, brought over and served to the children and the dishes are then returned and attended to by Mrs. Kerr. This school is provided with a kitchen and supplied with a stove and table. Two rooms adjoin it, one of which is supplied with a large white sink for dish-washing and a pump for soft water, and the other is equipped with a good enamel bath and looking glass. These rooms are only used for storage and are not even kept clean and tidy—all of which is wasted effort. The teacher should be instructed to see that these rooms are kept clean and tidy, and it is not understood why the preparation of the midday lunch could not be carried out in the room for that purpose. Miss Ruth Nelson, formerly of Kolakreela, Alla, writes this letter regarding her new experiences at the Moose Mountain School, Carlyle, Sask.: I found the children here so different even from the British Columbia Indians, but I now see quite a change in their "responsiveness." At noon I imagine I am back in a School Home, as we serve a hot lunch and have a washing up of dishes and children in our "annex." The department provides yarn, so, after work is done, the girls knit, and I now have most of the boys at it, too, the gramophone provides music, so we have quite an enjoyable half-hour. The children here have so few pleasures compared with those in boarding schools, or even on the British Columbia Reserves. The houses, too, are vastly different, the majority only one room. I believe the Department of Indian Affairs and also the Church consider this one of the most backward. Twenty years ago a deaconess and teacher did splendid work here. The folks in Carlyle have noticed a great improvement since the W.M.S. took over the work in 1929, and Miss Ferguson sees progress in the care of the homes and children. At present there are more attending school than before, as far back as I can find records. About sixteen are at boarding schools, most of them now at Brandon. Dr. Doyle paid us a visit in December, and I hope to see the new school there some time.

The life here is so very different from Kitamaat and Port Simpson—seems much more isolated here in many ways, although the town is only ten miles away. Sometimes I am seven weeks without going in, but the agent brings the mail out quite frequently. They tell me that in summer there are many visitors, the summer resort at the lake is leased from the reserve, and is quite a large and flourishing one, well populated, as the lake is the only large one in quite a distance. The reserve, I believe, comprises over thirty thousand acres, but has many swamps and bush, so that the arable land is not quite enough for the two hundred and fifty Indians. I do miss the green trees in winter—we had to camouflage a birch tree at Christmas time—but it served the purpose very nicely.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the White Bear Indian Day School, inspected on September 17th, 1931.

The school is in charge of Miss R. Nelson, who has had several years teaching experience with Indian pupils. Two years ago these children were very shy and backward and only in a few cases could they be induced to speak above a whisper. A vast change has been wrought in this respect and the children have obtained confidence in themselves and can be distinctly heard across the room when reading or speaking any oral work.

The roll calls for 21 pupils, 11 girls and 10 boys. I found 17 present.

The grades are arranged as follows:

- Grade 1 - 14
- Grade 2 - 2
- Grade 3 - 4
- Grade 4 - 1

I found the room clean, well aired and tidy. The floors had all been oiled and were in good condition. The windows were screened and the screen door on and in good repair. The class-room was almost free of flies.

The children were clean and well dressed. In all cases their hair had been neatly combed.

- The kitchen at -

The kitchen at the rear of the school was clean. The children are provided with individual cups, toothbrushes and towels, all of which were neatly arranged in the washroom and labelled with the pupils' names.

Since my last visit the foundation under this portion of the school has been repaired by a cement wall. The eavestroughing has also been put in good condition and outside windows provided. This room should now be much warmer and more comfortable both for the teacher and pupils.

A noon lunch is prepared by the pupils, supervised by Miss Nelson, and the girls are receiving a splendid training, which should be of great help to them at home.

All the pupils have been taught to knit and already they have mitts ready for winter use and in some cases socks and stockings have also been made.

The garden this year was a failure as it had been planted on poor land and lacked moisture badly. It is hoped that another year a better success will be made of this work.

The attendance during the first part of the month was somewhat irregular, as many of the children were away with their parents while they were putting up hay. However, they are home now and during the past week the attendance averaged 19.

The walls and ceiling of the class room are somewhat smoked and dull and another year will need to be repainted.

As stated above, Miss Nelson is doing excellent work and this is now one of the best managed day schools I am privileged to visit.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,
