Sir,

I have to inform the Department that Miss L.R. Nelson—the teacher at White Bear's Day School—is in poor health and appears to be on the verge of a nervous breakdown and, in consequence, should at once be relieved of her duties.

An incident occurred on Sunday night last in my presence at the mission house here which, after placing the matter before the United Church minister in Carlyle and discussing it with him, I felt obliged to report to the W.M.S. headquarters in Toronto.

The circumstances regarding the incident are as follow—

On Sunday night January 11th I was present at the mission house by invitation to partake of the evening meal with Miss Nelson, Miss Carnegie, and Mr. and Mrs. Bush—the two latter being of the Agency staff here. My wife is away in Edmonton Alta., undergoing hospital treatment under Dr. J.H. Conroy and a specialist who operated on her whilst we resided at the Edmonton City Agency. At the time I arrived at the mission Miss Carnegie was working in the kitchen preparing dinner. Miss Nelson was upstairs in her room, and Mrs. Bush was in the sitting-room from which she had a partial view of the kitchen. Mr. Bush had not yet arrived.

I was sitting near the kitchen table carrying on conversation with Miss Carnegie as she worked when Miss Nelson came downstairs and into the kitchen with her hat and coat on. She sat down at the opposite side of the table from me and commenced to put her overshoes on. I should explain before going any further that both Miss Nelson and Miss Carnegie had been suffering with colds and hoarseness for a few days, in fact Miss Nelson was unable to conduct the day school on Thursday and Friday of last week and I had to close it.

To resume my narrative—Miss Carnegie asked Miss Nelson where she was going and received a reply to the effect that she was going to make a fire as the children would be cold—apparently referring to making a fire in the day school to take the chill off in readiness for Monday morning. Miss Carnegie told Miss Nelson she was not fit to go out on such an errand and I intervened and offered to go and make the fire in the school if it was necessary. Miss Nelson thereupon put her arms on the table and laid her head on them, looking up two or three times to make rambling remarks about making the fire &c., and then suddenly without warning, stooped to the floor, picked up one of her overshoes and deliberately threw it across the room at Miss Carnegie, who had taken a seat near the kitchen range. The overshoe struck Miss Carnegie on the left shoulder and to say that Miss Carnegie and I were surprised is to put it mildly, in fact I may say that I was astounded, as I had previously had no idea that Miss Nelson could be guilty of such an act. After throwing the shoe Miss Nelson again dropped her head to her arms on the table and made other rambling remarks about wanting a taxi to take her to the station, and that she would miss her train if the taxi did not come soon &c. Finally Miss Carnegie persuaded Miss Nelson to retire again to her room.

contd.
(her room) and accompanied her, and so far as I know there were no more unpleasant incidents that night.

Subsequently I asked Miss Carnegie if she knew of any cause for Miss Nelson's action and she informed me that she believed that Miss Nelson was vexed with her because she had not held the Sunday School in proper form that afternoon when asked to do so by Miss Nelson, but as it was a cold and stormy day only four boys turned up and as Miss Carnegie was hoarse with a bad cold she did not consider it advisable to carry on the school, but she had made the fire in the chapel and made the other usual preparations and when only four Indians arrived she left them to warm and amuse themselves whilst she prepared the light lunch which it customary to provide after the Sunday afternoon service.

I have since been informed by Mrs Bush that she was present in the mission house on one occasion when Miss Nelson slapped Miss Ferguson (the former deaconess) across the face because Miss Ferguson would not do something in the way Miss Nelson wanted it, and on another occasion when Miss Nelson screamed in a hysterical manner because she could not have her own way.

I have received complaints from Indian parents that Miss Nelson has on occasion abused their children but, used as I am to the parents making all kinds of excuses in order to keep their children away from school, I took very little notice of these complaints, beyond mentioning them to Miss Nelson and being assured by her that there was no truth in them, until the incident which I witnessed on Sunday night caused me to believe that the parents' complaints might have some foundation.

The foregoing is virtually a copy of the report which I forwarded to Mrs Anson Spotton of the W.M.S. at Toronto and I trust my action was the correct one.

As it will doubtless be necessary to appoint another teacher to carry on the duties at the school I felt it incumbent on me to bring the matter to the attention of the Department as Mrs Spotton will also be compelled to place the matter before the Department.

Miss Nelson and Miss Carnegie reside together at the mission house and Miss Carnegie is apprehensive that Miss Nelson may commit some act of a more serious nature if her condition becomes worse. Miss Nelson is carrying on the school at present and I have not mentioned Sunday night's incident to her.

Carnegie R.M., the nurse at the United Church mission here, that a Miss Mary Blair has been recommended to the Department by the United Church as teacher for White Bear's Bay School for the term commencing September lst next, and that Miss Blair has stated, in a letter to Miss Carnegie, that she has had a conversation with Mr. Sutherland—the head of the Indian Dept., at Ottawa—in which he informed her that the school here would not open until Sept 5th, that being the day after Labor Day. I do not wish to question the policy of the Department in the operation of the schools but I really fail to see why it is necessary to bring in a teacher from Ottawa to take charge of this school when there are dozens of teachers (fully qualified) in Saskatchewan who would be glad to have the opportunity of taking it. I understand that Miss Blair is what is known as a missionary-teacher and I would say in this connection that the missionary part of the matter might as well be forgotten for all the good the Presbyterian and United Church missionaries have done here in the last thirty-five or forty years. A non-denominational teacher appointed by, and answerable only to, the Indian Department would be more suitable for this school, and could at present, I am sure, be obtained for a much lower salary than the $81 per month which the Department has been paying, as I know teachers in this district who are asking $40 to $50 per month for the coming term.

Dear Mr. Allen;—

I may be out of order in writing to you personally, but a matter has come up in connection with the operation of White Bear's Day School in which the question of the more economical financing is concerned, and which, in my opinion, may affect not only this school but also other Indian day schools. A new teacher is in charge of this school at the commencement of the term on Sept. 1st, and Miss Blair of Ottawa has been appointed after being recommended by the United Church, and her salary is to be at the rate of $80 per month less 10% or $81 per month.

The grades taught in this school rarely go beyond four and a teacher with a first class certificate is not necessary. An efficient teacher with late normal school training could be secured in this district at not more than $50 per month and so effect a saving in salary of $31 per month. I have an application on file from a Saskatchewan teacher holding first class certificate who asks $70 per month and even that is $11 less than Miss Blair is to receive.

I wrote the Department on this matter on August 8th and received a reply under reference 113-1-1 of August 16th to the effect that Miss Blair had been appointed and would receive the salary as stated.

If the Department is anxious to economise I do not see why it is necessary to pay $81 per month for a teacher when one just as good can be obtained for $50, and if a missionary-teacher is considered necessary I fail to see why the Department should pay for Church missionary work.

These Indians are a poverty stricken lot and it is far more necessary to provide for their material needs than for their spiritual needs at the present time and in this connection I would refer to my letters of April 26th and August 11th and Departmental 112-1-5 of May 2nd regarding provision for the noon meals at this school, and to point out that the amount which could be saved in one month on the teacher's salary would be sufficient to provide beef for soup for the pupils for six months.

I do not wish to create friction between the Department and myself, but the educational system under which these Indian Day schools are operated, under the auspices of one Church or another, is antiquated and should be reorganized. I will leave it to your discretion to take any or no action in this matter as you think fit but felt that having met you personally I could write you on a matter where finances are concerned.

Yours very truly,

MEMORANDUM:

Doctor McGill

There has been a small disagreement between Mr. Ostrander, who has lately taken the Moose Mountain Reserve into his Agency, and Miss Wardle, the nurse or social worker maintained by the United Church at this Reserve and to whose salary we contribute $50.00 per month. Mr. Ostrander took exception to her selling to the Indians supplies of clothing, and so forth, furnished from church sources for distribution at the Reserve. The matter was discussed by Reverend Kenneth J. Beaton on his last visit here, and he pointed out that for many years past it has been the custom of the Missionary Society of his church to make nominal charges for such supplies to Indians who could afford to pay. The supplies in question, of course, are mostly used clothing donated by church members all over the country. The church point of view is that it is undesirable to give supplies to anyone who can afford to make a small payment for them.

On December 12th Mr. Ostrander submitted this matter to the Department in a letter which you will see on this file, and in reply was informed that as Miss Wardle is an employee she is debarred by the Indian Act from selling these goods to the Indians.

I have no particular opinion on the matter, but I wish to point out that this custom is very widespread and has not usually, I think, been thought upon as an infraction to the Act. The Act makes no distinction between missionary workers employed by the Department and those who are not. It seems to be aimed at missionaries and Departmental employees engaged in regular trading operations.
Mr. Beaton submitted the matter to me and I agreed to have it settled, but I did not know at that time that Mr. Ostrander had been instructed. Apparently it has a wider application than this one Reserve, and in dealing with Mr. Beaton as the headquarters officer of his church, it seems to me we can scarcely make a ruling for one place only without enforcing it everywhere. I shall be pleased to have your direction.

E. L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services

Dear Mr. Beston,

The Director of Medical Services has brought to my attention the problem which you discussed with him on your last visit here of sale to Indians at the Moose Mountain Reserve, Saskatchewan, of clothing donated through the Board of Home Missions of your Church. Unknown to Doctor Stone, the Indian Agent, Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander, had consulted the Department in this matter in the month of December, last, and had been informed that Miss Wardle, as an employee of the Department, was debarred by the Indian Act from selling these goods to the Indians.

The Indian Act is specific in this matter. It states as follows:

"No official or employee connected with the inside or outside service of the Department, and no missionary in the employ of any religious denomination, or otherwise employed in mission work among Indians, and no school teacher on an Indian reserve, shall, without the special license in writing of the Superintendent General, trade with any Indian, or sell to him directly or indirectly, any goods or supplies, cattle or other animals."

I am informed that the custom of collecting from Indians who are able to pay for the supplies in question in this case has prevailed for many years, and I do not think that the prohibition in the Indian Act was aimed at it. My opinion is that it was designed rather to prevent systematic trading operations on the part of Departmental employees and missionaries. The problem, however, has been presented in

Dear Dr. McGill:

Re: Interpretation of Indian Act

I did not reply immediately to your letter of March 23rd, because I wanted to go very carefully into this whole situation. I discover that the problem raised in your communication is not a new one, but that even as far back as twenty years ago it was a matter of discussion between the Board of Home Missions of the Methodist Church and the Department of Indian Affairs.

This is the second time in the five years that I have been in this office that the same Agent has raised the problem and attempted to get a ruling from the Department unfavorable to the missionary. On a previous occasion, he tried to get a ruling against Rev. R. J. Ross, the Principal of the Round Lake Residential School, on just as trivial and unimportant grounds as the issue which he raises now.

I do not believe that the clause in the Indian Act quoted in your letter ever was intended to be interpreted as indicated. Very careful calculation reveals the fact that the women of the United Church, through their organizations, send on to the fifty Indian Missions for which we are responsible bales of new and used clothing to a value considerably in excess of $10,000 annually. In every case, the practice which is followed is to care for the women and the old people first in the distribution of quilts, underwear and other garments. Able-bodied Indians are expected to pay a small sum for the clothing which they receive. This helps somewhat to get away from the extreme paternalism of previous missionary administration. An Indian who pays $1.50 to $2.00 for a perfectly good suit of clothes is certainly not being seriously discriminated against. The money which is received from these sales is expended in the purchase of milk and other things not included in indigent rations as they are provided by the Department. There are always sick people and delicate infants who give the missionary on the average Reserve a good deal of concern.

So far as I have been able to think the problem through up to the present, if your letter of March 23rd is the final word of the Department on the question, there are three courses of action open to the Mission Boards:-
(1) To cease sending these bales entirely and place the responsibility for the clothing needs of the women and children on the Department, where it rightfully belongs.

(2) To take a trial case before a judge and get an official interpretation of the Act. I have been accustomed to consult Hon. N. W. Rowell, K.C., in regard to matters affecting our Indian administration, but he has been absent at the Privy Council and I have not had opportunity to raise this question with him as yet.

(3) To agitate for an amendment to the Indian Act, through our friends in the House of Commons, which will make perfectly clear our position in regard to this matter.

The Reserve at Moose Mountain is of course a comparatively small one but the amazing speed with which news travels from tribe to tribe in Western Canada will probably assure the knowledge of this ruling of the Department being the common property of every Indian Chief before next Fall.

I expect to be in Ottawa on Thursday and will be glad to talk with you further about this whole problem.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir:—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 113-1-1 of the 2nd instant in connection with the suggested erection of a day school at the White Bear Indian Reserve.

As you are no doubt aware the building which is at present being used as a day school is very old and hardly worth spending a great deal of money on and will accommodate less than one half of the available pupils from that Reserve.

If the Department seriously considers the erection of a day school at that point would it not be advisable to erect a two room day school sufficiently large to accommodate from 70 to 75 pupils.

On the rolls of the day school at present there are 29 pupils, a further 9 pupils are now of age to attend school and 12 more will be old enough by the time a new school could be erected. There are 12 R.C. children of this Reserve attending Residential Schools, 11 at the Qu'Appelle School and 1 at the Cowessess I.R.School and 3 Protestant children attending the Brandon School.

The three schools mentioned are well able to fill their quota without taking any children from White Bear Reserve and I am sure that if a 2 room undenominational school were in operation the children would be receiving useful education at a much lower per capita cost.

The available children of school age by the beginning of next term after allowing for five possible discharges would be 60 of which about one half are members of the R.C. Church and the other half members of the United Church and while I do not wish the Department to feel that any favoritism is shown in the day school for members of either church under the present arrangement I believe that a day school operated strictly under Departmental Supervision with the teachers responsible only to the Department would be more satisfactory to all.

If the Department decides to erect a 2 room day school it should be erected at a point approximately one mile directly west of the present day school then the greatest distance that a child would have to travel to school would be 3 miles and I believe that the operation of one 2 roomed day school together with a small outlay for transportation during bad weather would be more economical than the operation of two small schools which would be perhaps 3 miles apart.

There is another point which deserves some consideration viz:- the fact that the present day school is operated more or less under the auspices of the United Church and as the two denominations are evenly divided I presume that a second day school would be expected by the R.C. authorities to be run under their auspices, then the question immediately arises in connection with transportation of R.C. children from the east side of the reserve to the west and vice versa. A 2 roomed school operated strictly by the Department would overcome this difficulty.

As I have no idea what the views of the Department are in this matter I am pointing out the circumstances as I view them and I shall be glad to furnish any further information which might be of assistance.

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs

Ottawa

Your obedient servant,

J.F.B. Ostrander

Mr. Ostrander mentions in his letter that the question of providing a second day school at the west end of this reserve (White Bear Reserve, Moose Mountain Agency) has been suggested. In this connection I am inclined to favour his idea of providing a two roomed school sufficiently large to accommodate the pupilage available at a point which would be central. By changing the location of the school, it would be possible to have approximately eighty per cent of the children residing within one mile and very few at a greater distance than one and one half miles from the site he proposes. There are at present sixty children of school age on the reserve and indications are that as time goes on this number will be substantially increased. Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 113-1-1, dated the 6th of August last. This letter arrived during my absence on holiday and immediately upon my return I called up Indian Agent McKenzie and asked him to come to Regina when convenient and confer with me regarding this and other matters in connection with his Agency. I may say that upon enquiry I find that our Protestant Residential Schools have now all the children in residence that they can accommodate and have waiting lists. When submitting the Estimates for the File Hills Residential School, an item was inserted for an addition to that school to enable the Principal to accommodate a larger number of pupils and he had in mind taking in the surplus children from the White Bear's Reserve.

After talking the matter over with Mr. McKenzie, I am of the opinion that it would be more satisfactory to the Indians on the White Bear Reserve if an addition were made to the Round Lake United Church Residential School. The White Bear Reserve is situated about 65 miles from the Round Lake School and many of the Indians on the White Bear Reserve are related to Indians on the Reserves surrounding the Round Lake School. They therefore look with more favor upon the Round Lake School than they do on the File Hills School, as the File Hills School is about 140 miles from their Reserve. It will be readily seen that the Round Lake School would be a more desirable point for these children to -

Dear Mr. Christenson,

I am in receipt of the Department communication re. the closing of Indian Day Schools during the month of September. I am quite in sympathy with the need for economy during the present crisis and am entirely in agreement with a salary cut. But I have been wondering if it would effect any noticeable economy to close the school as well. In other words, I am quite willing to teach during the month of September without a pay cheque if the Department will but grant me permission to open the school for that month.

If the Department is willing for this to be done the only expense would be the cost of the pencils and scribblers used by the pupils during that month. A matter of hardly one dollar. All other expenditures such as janitor work and mid-day lunch could be so arranged that they would not increase the amount the government are prepared to allow for the nine months they suggest school be open.

Here are a few of the reasons why I consider it would be undesirable to close White Bear's School during September.

We have no attendance problem at this school as our quarterly reports will indicate. As the majority of our pupils are juniors they are not kept out to assist with haying and other Fall work. Last September our attendance was over 97%.

I have been trying for the past two years to cultivate an interest in school on the part of both pupils and parents. I feel that this has been partly achieved and I am afraid that a prolonged holiday might create another state of apathy.

This year we have increased the school garden until it consists of almost half an acre. This has been divided up into four plots and a different group of children made responsible for each plot. Quite an enthusiastic competition has resulted and an interested outsider has donated a prize for the best plot. But if the school is closed for July, August and September the weeds will win the competition.
In view of the above facts, and in view of the fact that Moose Mountain, being such a backward Reserve, requires all the educational exposure it can get, I would like to operate during September.

I am not concerned over the salary but I am concerned over the welfare of my pupils. After all, I am in Indian work because I am keenly interested in Indian education and not because of financial remuneration. To me it is 'experimental education' and ten months is none too long a period for the conducting of the experiment. I very willingly give up my September salary cheque, but I very unwillingly give up September school.

As school can be operated during September with practically no additional expense for the government I would greatly appreciate it if the Department would grant me permission to open the school on September 4th. in accordance with the regular schedule.

Yours sincerely,

"Mabel K. Waywell"

Report on White Bear Indian Day School

I wish to report on an inspection made on the above mentioned school on the White Bear Reserve, Carlyle, Saskatchewan. This school is situated just a short distance from the old Agency where the Farming Instructor, Mr. J.R. Morrison, now resides.

The building is in fair state of repair and does not require any decorating, etc. in the near future. The number of children on the roll is 33 and the average attendance is 30. This is quite outstanding. At the back of the school building there is an additional room which is used as a kitchen. The children eat their lunch on their desks and they have a mat which fits on the desk while they are eating.

Near the school the United Church of Canada own a Mission House where the teacher resides and also the nurse together with the man who looks after the chores around the place and his wife. I believe the Church Authorities pay part of the salary of the chore man, and the teacher and the nurse augment the remainder out of their own salary.

Mrs. K. Waywell, the teacher, is very energetic and I would say she is obtaining good results.

I wish to point out here that she has no cupboard room at the school for books and stationary, and her desk consists of an old rickety table. If the Department would furnish her with some cupboards that can be built on the wall, and a teacher's desk, I am sure it would be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

I wish to inform you that this week I spent a couple of days on the White Bear Reserve at Carlyle, and while there I visited the Day School. I found that there were 30 children on the register, and this last quarter the average attendance there has been 18.

The school I am afraid will need a lot of repairing. The shingles will have to be renewed as the place is beginning to leak. The nails in the shingles have all worked up. I suppose that has been done gradually by wind and by looking at the roof you can see all the nails just simply with the point of the nail sticking into the shingle. I do not know whether the shingles are good enough to stand re-nailing or not. I believe it would be better to put new shingles on than try to patch the old ones by re-nailing them. However, this will be looked into.

The interior of the class room also needs painting. No decorating has been done for several years and the room is dark and dingy and certainly needs brightening up. Mr. Kerley will go into the matter of repairs for the school in due course, so they can be

........carried out
carried out through the holidays.

There are probably about 20 children of school age that were born in '35 that will attend school this year for the first time. I spoke to Mr. Kerley, Mr. Morrison, the Farming Instructor, the Teacher and the Nurse about the attendance of the children. I also spoke to the Chief and Councillor regarding this matter, pointing out that to keep up the attendance at the school was very important. I realize that there are times in the winter when the weather is cold, that there are reasons for the children staying home as some of them live about four miles from the school, but I am sure my talking to the Staff and the Indians will bring about some improvement.

They had good gardens at the School and I found that the teacher, Miss Cass, is no doubt doing her very best and is very much interested. Miss P. M. Hadland, the nurse, who rooms with the teacher, I believe is also doing very good work on the Reserve.

(i) A self-contained domestic establishment means a dwelling house, apartment or other similar place of residence containing at least one bedroom, in which resides the employee as a general rule sleeps and lives.

(ii) A person connected with the employee by marriage means the wife or husband, parents, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, grandparents and great-grandparents of employee's wife or husband, stepchildren, brother-in-law, sister-in-law.

(iii) A person connected with the employee by blood relationship means parents, foster parents, grandparents, great-grandparents, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, brothers, sisters, uncles or aunts, nephews, nieces.

(iv) Connection with the employee by adoption shall include adoption in fact as well as legal adoption.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Your letter of July 28 was forwarded to me here as I came for Aug. 1st.

The course I attended at Scarritt College Rural Centre gave credits on a B.R.E. degree and since I had never attempted to procure one I did not work for credits. We had lectures on Rural Sociology and Anthropology etc., and did observation work at various schools for the mountain and negro people. I was sorry that I couldn't have spent longer on the one Indian Reserve we visited, the Cherokee. On my various furloughs I have attended lectures similar to the above and done observation work but I never have done so with the intention any type of Certificate. Perhaps I made a mistake in not doing so but it is too late now. However I was pleased while at Crossville to meet an eminent sociologist who had somewhat the same views, but I see where that doesn't help set a salary schedule!

It is eighteen years since I came to this reserve for a short term of work and I see many changes, the population being much larger but the roads are no better especially as there has been rain, that too is rather a change for I was here during the time when it was too dry.

With kind regards I am,

Yours sincerely,

Ruth Nelson

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Just after you had left my office last week, I received a letter from Mr. Ostrander with regard to Miss Ruth Nelson, teacher at the above school.

I had written to him in connection with the Provincial School Inspector's report on Miss Nelson's work at this school. This report, submitted after a visit of November 9, 1948, indicated that Miss Nelson is proving unsatisfactory as a teacher at this school. On the teacher grading scale she received a B for Health and Language, a C for Appearance, Personality, Initiative, Discipline, and a D for Relations, Management, Teacher Skill, Preparations and Pupils' Progress. In other words, she is graded as poor in the most important items on the teacher grading scale.

In his general comments, Mr. Thomson states as follows:

"I was very unfavourably impressed with work being carried on this year in the White Bear School. Although the present teacher has had much experience in Indian Schools, she continues to teach the academic subjects only. School hours would appear to be irregular. No time-table is being used, although the time-table of the last teacher is still on the wall. Pupils rarely speak and then only in a whisper.

"There is a strong antagonistic spirit in the school. The pupils quarrel and fight. To avoid this..."
Miss Nelson sends those going East and those going West home at different times with the girls and boys at different times. All were, however, sent home close enough together to permit the last to overtake the first, and the segregation tended only to emphasize the ill will. One or two parents came for their children. The school cannot enjoy a successful year under present conditions."

I was rather perturbed at this report and so searched our files for an inspector's report upon Miss Nelson's work at Ahousaht. Unfortunately, we do not have such a report on our files, which is probably due to the fact that she was there during the period when we had no District Inspector of Schools for British Columbia. Mr. Indian Superintendent Kerley apparently knew of Miss Nelson when she was teaching at the Round Lake Residential School and also at the File Hills Residential School. In both these cases she had the assistance of the Principal in maintaining discipline, but now that she is on her own, the discipline is poor.

Mr. Ostrander feels that Miss Nelson's work is unsatisfactory and that she has not the ability to keep order or to teach when left to her own resources in an Indian day school.

They both recommend that Mrs. J. R. Morrison, wife of the Assistant Indian Agent at the above Reserve be considered as a temporary replacement for Miss Nelson. As you are probably aware, Mrs. Morrison has had many years of teaching experience, has a first class certificate, and formerly taught at the school in question, where her services were quite satisfactory. Mr. Dobbin made a favourable impression on the academic work and discipline at this school. I would not like to see it continue to deteriorate under Miss Nelson and would appreciate hearing from you in this regard.

Bernard F. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

We join with you in not liking the idea of seeing the school deteriorating under Miss Nelson, but we wonder whether it would be possible for Miss Nelson to continue until the end of the year. If this were possible, we would at once communicate to her the fact that the Inspector's report had been so unfavorable, and both by letter and by conference we would try to get her to improve sufficiently to get by. I rather think that it would be very helpful if we had a married man and his wife on that Reserve; but that is not the point at issue.

Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, I beg to refer you to official letter of the 30th ultimo, in which you were informed that the salaries of teachers of Indian Day Schools will be paid monthly in future. In the case of the White Bear Indian Day School, it has been the practice of the Department to forward the teacher's salary cheque to the Women's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada. However, present regulations require salary cheques to be issued direct to the person doing the work. Consequently, Miss Blair's cheque for the month of April was forwarded direct to her, and she should cash it.

As you are aware, the salary of the teacher at the White Bear School is $900 a year, payable on a ten month basis. For the past two years, there has been a 10% deduction from all salaries, but, on reference to the last paragraph of circular letter of the 30th ultimo, you will note that persons being paid under $1,000 are not reduced this year. Consequently, Miss Blair was paid at her own salary rate. As far as the Department can see, she should return the cheque which she received from the Women's Missionary Society.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the White Bear School in the Moose Mountain agency, inspected on January 13th, 1927.

This school is of frame structure and will accommodate about 32 children. It is the old style school with three large windows on both sides. The blackboard extends across the front with one piece on each side and rear wall. The side and rear pieces of board are badly worn and are of little use.

There is an outside entrance where the children hang their coats and wraps. This was clean and tidy. The floor in this entrance was badly worn, in fact, a hole was worn through it. The school-room was clean. The floor in this room is badly worn and very difficult to keep clean.

The number of Indian children enrolled is 22; -Boys 16 and girls 6, and the highest grade is Grade III. Some of these children have about 2½ or 3 miles to come and yet the attendance as shown by the register is fairly good.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
I noticed the window blinds were poor and not in working order, and a number of the seats are very old and about ready to fall apart. The stove is a box heater; quite satisfactory but one corner is broken. This allows the ashes and sparks to escape and there is always a danger from fire.

The discipline was good. The children were neat and clean. Their school work was fair. These children are very self-conscious and it is difficult to get them to either speak or read very loudly. I believe the teacher devotes considerable time to this part of his work. Their writing and arithmetic was good, and their exercise books clean and the work neatly done.

Mr. Kerr, the teacher, holds a Second Class Professional and I believe he is doing good work. He is very interested in the welfare of the Indian children.

Mrs. Kerr prepares the noon-day meal for these children in her own home and it is then taken across to the school for the children to eat. I was not present at the noon-hour but I believe the children receive abundance. The dinner consists of soup and biscuits, sometimes boiled vegetables and rice.

I might add, in addition to the Indian children, five white children attend. Some of these I believe, are in Grades VIII and IX. These children belong to the teacher and agent on the reserve.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

REGINA, SASK., January 19th, 1927.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a short report on the White Bear School in the Moose Mountain Agency, which was visited by Inspector Hamilton on the 12th of the present month.

With reference to that portion of the report which deals with the floor of the school, it seems to me that as this floor is very old and worn it would be a mistake to try to repair it, and that a new floor should be put in. I believe it would cost approximately $100.00 to have this work done.

I think that it would be well to supply the school with new window blinds. This would cost about $20.00. I would also recommend that a new heater be purchased, at a cost of about $30.00, as you will note the Inspector says there is a danger of fire with the heater at present in use.

You will note that Inspector Hamilton speaks well of Mr. Kerr and his wife, and that he found the children clean and the discipline good.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 113-1-5 of 5th inst regarding suggested changes in the lighting system at the Day School on this reserve. It will be of decided advantage to make the proposed changes which will make the lighting of the school more in accord with modern methods. Sir:

The Department has received the report of Mr. Inspector Hamilton on his recent visit to the White Bear Indian Day School. I have to request that you will draw to the attention of the teacher the following remarks of the Inspector:

He states that while the classroom was tidy and clean, the wash basins and the bench upon which they are kept were not in a cleanly condition; further, that the teacher did not have the children wash before lunch. The teacher should insist upon cleanliness of person among the pupils, and, as there are facilities provided for the purpose, he should see that the children wash up before partaking of lunch.

He further states that the soup for the noonday meal is made by Mrs. Kerr in her home, brought over and served to the children and the dishes are then returned and attended to by Mrs. Kerr. This school is provided with a kitchen and supplied with a stove and table. Two rooms adjoin it, one of which is supplied with a large white sink for dish-washing and a pump for soft water, and the other is equipped with a good enamel bath and looking glass. These rooms are only used for storage and are not even kept clean and tidy - all of which is wasted effort. The teacher should be instructed to see that these rooms are kept clean and tidy, and it is not understood why the preparation of the midday lunch could not be carried out in the room for that purpose. You should draw this matter to the attention of the teacher and have him carry out the above requirements of the Department.

The Inspector states, further, that the fence about the school is in a disgraceful condition, as many of the posts have rotted off, and the wire is badly bent and twisted. We understand that you have been instructed by Mr. Commissioner Graham to have the teacher, himself, fix the fence and arrange to have a garden plot broken.

I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the above requirements.

Referring to your No. 113-1-5, of the 11th instant, informing me that funds are available for the painting required at the White Bear Indian Day School, and also instructing me to take steps to have the fence put in good condition, as the Rev. Mr. Barner was of the opinion that the teacher could hardly be expected to do this work, I beg to say that the painting at this institution has been completed, but notwithstanding Mr. Barner's report I consider it is the duty of the teacher to keep this small fence in repair. If little jobs of this kind are not to be looked after by the local teacher, where are we going to end? However, I instructed the Agent to have this fence repaired, after I knew the condition in which it was found.

Inspector Hamilton visited this school during the summer, and he points out that he found the children were not washing before taking their midday meal, and that Mr. Kerr, when this matter was brought to his attention, said it would take too much time. I think this pretty well indicates the kind of a man Mr. Kerr is. The Inspector also points out that the kitchen which was provided in this school at the request of the church authorities, and furnished with a stove, table, sink and pump, also another room containing a good enamel bath, looking glass, etc., are never used, and that these rooms are not even kept clean, but are used as store-rooms. Nurse Lucas, as late as last month reports on this school as follows,- "The kitchen at the back was in a very untidy condition and is not used for the children, nor is the cook stove used to teach the children to cook." She also states that the toilets were in a dirty and unsanitary condition. Now, there is -no excuse-

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
no excuse for conditions of this kind existing, and it is very discouraging for our officers, especially the Agent and Inspectors, to have to contend with a man of this kind in keeping the school premises and property of the Department as they should be kept, to say nothing of the training of the children. If Mr. Kerr is under the impression that it is the duty of our Agent to go and look after such matters as the toilets and the repairing of the fence, etc., I think the Department should put him straight on this point. These teachers will have to take some responsibility, and there is too much of a feeling at large that the Department has to run and do every little trifling thing that is to be done. This applies not only to this school, but to other places as well, and I should be glad if these teachers and others were given to understand that they must shoulder some of this responsibility as well. Any teacher in a country school would be expected to keep the premises in good order, and this should be expected all the more in the case of a teacher living right at the school, who is supposed to be teaching the Indian children in sanitary habits, and matters of economy.

Only a short time ago I received a letter from Mr. Kerr, informing me that he was obliged to supply vegetables from his own garden to put in the soup that is used for the midday meal given to the children. I think this matter is so small and trifling that it is scarcely worth mentioning, but it will give you a further idea as to the kind of man Mr. Kerr is, and the difficulty the Inspectors and Agent have with him. I am of the opinion that if he were to receive a letter from the Department it would have the effect of letting him know that he has some obligations in connection with this school, and would make matters better for everyone concerned.

We have not the staff to do the kind of work these schools expect us to do, and matters are getting worse instead of better.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

REGINA, SASK.—June 15th, 1929.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the White Bear Indian Day School, inspected June 13th, while at the Moose Mountain Agency.

The roll at this school calls for 18 children and 11 were present. The grades range as follows:

Grade I - 9 pupils
" II - 4 "
" III - 4 "
" IV - 1 "

The average attendance for the quarter ending March 31st was 8.74. However, since that date the attendance has improved, averaging about 10 or 12.

The pupils were neatly clad and were clean, and I noticed that their hair was neatly combed. They appeared fairly well along in their work, although there is no outstanding progress. The work in the exercise books was fairly neat, although the books were not kept clean.

The classroom was tidy, but as there were no screens on the windows a great many large flies swarmed about the room and disturbed the attention of the children. In order that the room be properly aired, it is necessary to keep these windows open and screens should be provided as it will be impossible to remain in the room when the mosquitoes become bad. A screen door should also be provided.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

A new fence
A new fence was erected last year around the school property and this has greatly improved the appearance of the place.

A small garden plot was broken, but will not be put into garden this year. The Agent intends to have it properly worked and made ready for garden purposes next year.

I found some repair work was needed on the toilets and these also need to be thoroughly cleaned. The Agent had instructed this work to be done, but apparently he was misunderstood, and assured me that the repair work would be carried out, as well as having them properly cleaned.

Mr. C. B. Kerr, the teacher who has been in charge for the past two years, will be leaving at the end of the present term, and I understand that a lady is being appointed by the Church to work with Miss Ferguson, a Deaconess, who is also appointed by the Church. I have no doubt that this change will be an improvement as I found it very difficult for Mr. Kerr to adapt himself to the teaching of Indian children. No doubt, if this change is made, some repair work will be needed to the kitchen in connection with the school. As pointed out in previous reports, this kitchen has never been used since Mr. Kerr was placed in charge, and the children receive no instruction in the preparation of meals or in the washing of dishes. No doubt the new teacher and deaconess will wish to carry out this line of work and this will necessitate a certain amount of repair work. The basement to the kitchen is infested with rats and already they have gnawed through the floor, which will now need to be repaired.
The tank used as a cistern has been left to freeze and no doubt is destroyed. However, this could be removed and a smaller tank installed which would be large enough, no doubt, to meet the requirements.

I understand that an amount was placed in the Estimates for these repairs and, if granted, the school can be put in first class shape before the fall term opens.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the White Bear Indian Day School inspected April 4th, 1930.

Since my last inspection Miss M. K. Anderson has been appointed teacher. Miss Anderson holds her 2nd Class certificate, and has had a number of years teaching experience. She presents the lessons in an interesting manner and is obtaining good results.

The roll calls for 16 pupils, 10 boys and 6 girls. The grades are arranged as follows,- Grade 1 - 7; Grade 2 - 9. This is the first time since I have inspected the school that I have been able to hear the children read so as to be heard at any distance. There is still room for improvement, but I believe in time Miss Anderson will accomplish it. Some of these children are 12 to 14 years of age, and should at least be in Grade 5 or 6; however up till this year the school has been at a stand still. I believe if Miss Anderson remains the Department can expect marked improvement in the children. The discipline is good.

The children were fairly well dressed, and were clean and tidy in appearance.

A noon-day lunch is provided which consists of soup and biscuits. The girls prepare the meal and wash the dishes. Miss Anderson remains at school during the noon hour and supervises the work as well as the children's recreation.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6294, file 624-5, part 2)
I noticed that the children have individual drinking cups, as well as towels and combs, and apparently these are all made use of.

The school building is in good repair. Outside windows were provided and these greatly improved conditions, as it was difficult to heat the building previously.

This year an effort will be made to have a school garden. This side of the work has had practically no attention during the past and the garden usually turned out to be little better than a weed patch. Miss Anderson is interested in outside work, and I am sure the work will be carried on equally as well as is the classroom work.

The attendance during the past few months has dropped so that the average ranges between 9 and 10. Some of the children live a distance of about 3 miles from the school, and lately the roads have been very bad. As soon as the snow is gone I would expect a much better attendance. I am pleased to report the marked change at this school, and I feel the Department is fortunate in the appointment of Miss Anderson as teacher.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report made by Inspector Hamilton on the White Bear Indian Day School, in the Moose Mountain Agency.

The report is quite favourable. Matters in connection with this school have greatly improved in the last year, and I am looking for even further improvement in the coming year.

A few years ago we did supply this school with the necessary tools to work a garden, but they never made a success of the work. I feel, however, that the people who are now in charge of the school will take more interest in this particular line of work and we shall have some results.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK. June 16th, 1931.

Inspector Hamilton's report on White Bear Indian Day School, Moose Mountain Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the White Bear Indian Day School, inspected on June 11th, 1931.

The teacher in charge is Miss L. R. Nelson. The roll calls for 23 pupils, and I found 12 present. The average for May was 15.9, and the June attendance, so far, is higher. The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 16     |
| II    | 4      |
| III   | 3      |

The children appeared to be well along in their grades, and a marked improvement can be noted in the manner in which they read and speak. Two years ago they could scarcely speak beyond a whisper and appeared too shy and frightened to attempt answering the most simple questions; today such is not the case.

The children were fairly well clothed, neat in appearance, and clean. All had their hair neatly combed.

The classroom was tidy and bright. A screen door has been provided, also screens for the windows, so that I found the room well aired and free of flies.

A noon-day meal is provided, and this is prepared in the school kitchen by the girls, under the supervision of the teacher. I found the kitchen tidy,

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6294, file 624-5, part 2)
and the wash sink clean. The children are provided with individual towels and cups. Miss Nelson is the first teacher for years to make use of the kitchen, which is fairly well equipped and most suitable for the work. However, if this room is to be used during the coming winter, some work will be needed on the foundation, and storm windows should be provided. The room is on the north side of the building and is very cold and draughty.

The eavetroughing needs repairing as most of the water is lost before it reaches the cistern. The soft water is used for dishwashing and for the children.

A garden was planted, but, due to the extremely dry weather, has made little headway, and I doubt if it will amount to much.

Miss Nelson is doing excellent work, and I was delighted with the manner in which the work is carried on.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith Inspector Hamilton's report on the White Bear Indian Day School, in the Moose Mountain Agency.

It seems to me the Department should provide for the repairs required to the kitchen. In the Estimates we asked for $50.00 for interior painting and $12.00 for repairs to the eavetroughing. I do not know whether or not this has been allowed, but if it has I believe we could make the necessary repairs to the kitchen and eavetroughing for $62.00 and the painting could stand over for another year. I have not the exact figures but I do not think it should be much more than this amount.

Sir,

I beg to inform the Department that on a recent visit to White Bear's Day School I found that the soft water tank in the cellar is badly damaged and will have to be replaced. This tank is 8 ft long, 6 ft wide, and 6 ft deep, is rectangular in shape, constructed of galvanised iron encased in a plank form for support. The tank was constructed close against the earth side of the cellar, and the planks on one side have now become rotten through contact with the earth and have allowed the earth wall to cave in and break one long side of the tank.

There is no well at the school and soft water storage is depended on entirely for cleansing purposes—drinking water is carried from the well at the mission which is about 150 yards away.

The present tank has several times previously developed leaks and has been repaired but it is now beyond repair; it appears to have been in use since the additions were built on to the school many years ago.

I would suggest that one or two round galvanised tanks be installed in place of the old tank, with a storage capacity of 40 to 50 barrels.

I included an item of $200 in the Estimates for 1933/4 for repairs at this school.

Please instruct me.

Your obedient servant,

E.W. Stephenson
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, March 15, 1933.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the condition of the soft water tank in the cellar at the White Bear's Indian Day School. It is noted that the present tank is now beyond repair and that you recommend the installation of two round galvanized tanks, with a storage capacity of 40 to 50 barrels.

In this connection I have to request that you will furnish an estimate of the cost of supplying one galvanized tank of sufficient capacity to meet the requirements. It is considered that it should not be necessary to provide water storage to the capacity stated by you, but that one tank having a capacity of, say, from 12 to 15 barrels would store sufficient water to meet all requirements at this school. Our funds will be so limited next fiscal year that it may not be possible to provide the expenditure required in furnishing and installing the tank. We will await your estimate before deciding whether authority can be granted or not. Please furnish full particulars as to the type and size of tank you would recommend for the purpose and what work would be necessary in connection with the installation.

Regarding the item which you placed in your estimates for repairs at this school, I have to say that it was not possible to provide same in the estimates of this Department for the coming fiscal year.

Sir,-

Re White Bear's Day School in this Agency.

It has been customary at this school to serve a noon meal to the pupils. The food provided has been beef soup, biscuits, vegetables when available, or boiled rice and milk—the latter prepared from milk powder.

I shall be pleased to be informed whether or not this practice may be continued.

The school re-opened on Monday 24th inst after the Easter recess and the attendance has been very good for the three days—on Monday 23 pupils were present, on Tuesday-25, and today-25.

In the case of some of the pupils I am aware that the meal received at the school is the best one obtained during the day.

The older girls prepare the meal under the supervision of the teacher, and thus receive instruction in simple culinary methods.

In the Estimates for 1933/4 I included items of biscuits, soap, rice, drimilk, rolled oats, and beef. The biscuits have now been received but the invoices have not yet come to hand. I shall be glad to know if any of the items requested under the heading of equipment have been allowed.

Sir:—

I find that there is very little bread being made by the Indians of the White Bears Band and very little effort has been made by the Indians in this connection in the past. I have talked to the Indians considerably on this question and it seems that the chief reason why very little bread is baked is in the fact that so few of them have stoves fit for baking. I have always looked upon the use of bread instead of bannock as a very progressive step in improving the Indian's home conditions and I have wondered if the Department would consider using Band Funds of this Band for the purchase of stoves where they are needed and where they will be used for this purpose.

I would submit two reasons that in my opinion are good ones for this step, first that the use of bread instead of bannock saves a great deal of flour, second that the children of this Reserve attend the Day-school and walk a distance of from two to eight miles per day going to and from school and I found upon enquiries from 22 pupils that only two have bread in their homes, the remainder having only bannock and a majority of those using bannock make this daily trip with absolutely nothing in their stomachs but a piece of bannock and a cup of tea. As the mid-day meal at this school has been discontinued reference Dept. Letter 113-1-5 March 18th last, the majority of the children will be badly undernourished and not fit for the walking expected of them and I expect that irregular school attendance will be the result.

If the Department is not prepared to approve of the supplying of stoves I beg to enquire whether consideration would be given to the expenditure of an amount not exceeding $100.00 per annum from Band Funds, the money to be used for providing a mid-day meal to the children at school.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 113-1-1 of the 2nd instant in connection with the suggested erection of a day school at the White Bear Indian Reserve.

As you are no doubt aware the building which is at present being used as a day school is very old and hardly worth spending a great deal of money on and will accommodate less than one half of the available pupils from that Reserve.

If the Department seriously considers the erection of a day school at that point would it not be advisable to erect a two-room day school sufficiently large to accommodate from 70 to 75 pupils.

On the rolls of the day school at present there are 29 pupils, a further 9 pupils are now of age to attend school and 12 more will be old enough by the time a new school could be erected. There are 12 R.C. children of this Reserve attending Residential Schools, 11 at the Qu'Appelle School and 1 at the Cowessess I.R. School and 3 Protestant children attending the Brandon School.

The three schools mentioned are well able to fill their quota without taking any children from White Bear Reserve and I am sure that if a 2-room undenominational school were in operation the children would be receiving a useful education at a much lower per capita cost.

The available children of school age by the beginning of next term after allowing for five possible discharges would be 60 of which about one half are members of the R.C. Church and the other half members of the United Church and while I do not wish the Department to feel that any favoritism is shown in the day school to members of either church under the present arrangement I believe that a day school operated strictly under Departmental Supervision with the teachers responsible only to the Department would be more satisfactory to all.

If the Department decides to erect a 2-room day school it should be erected at a point approximately one mile directly west of the present day school then the greatest distance that any child would have to travel to school would be 3 miles and I believe that the operation of one 2-roomed day school together with a small outlay for transportation during bad weather would be more economical than the operation of two small schools which would be perhaps 3 miles apart.

There is another point which deserves some consideration viz:- the fact that the present day school is operated more or less under the auspices of the United Church and as the two denominations are evenly divided I presume that a second day school would be expected by the R.C. Authorities to be run under their auspices, therefore the question immediately arises in connection with transportation of R.C. children from the east side of the reserve to the west and vice versa. A 2-roomed school operated strictly by the Department would overcome this difficulty.

As I have no idea what the views of the Department are in this matter I am pointing out the circumstances as I view them and I shall be glad to furnish any further information which might be of assistance.

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander

I have had a letter from the teacher at the White Bear Bay School regarding the need for food supplies for the mid-day meal for the pupils at that school and she has also mentioned the matter of purchasing and keeping a cow in order to provide milk.

With regard to the milk question I certainly do not approve of the supplying of a cow and it would be nothing but a source of trouble but Drimilk has been used some time ago at that point and I understand was found satisfactory.

I have advised her that I am taking up the matter with the Department. I would be glad to be advised as to what money will be available this year for that purpose.

I may state that the Indians on this Reserve are very poor, the children have to come to school in many cases 3 to 4 miles on foot and practically the only decent meal they have in the course of the day is the meal provided at the school and that has been rather on the small side lately.

I appreciate the financial difficulty is the main question but I feel that in this case it is a matter of money exceptionally well expended as besides placing the children in a far better condition to receive the education offered them it greatly benefits their physical condition and I have no hesitation in strongly recommending that the Department consider this as favourably as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. P. B. Ostrander
Indian Agent

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, requesting a further amount for midday meal purposes at the White Bear's Indian Day School. This is the only provision that our funds will permit us allowing and, therefore, it will not be possible to grant the further amount requested in your recent letter. Sir:-

I beg to advise that I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. C.F. I understand however from the Farm Instructor that temporary repairs could be made at a cost not exceeding five dollars. May this authority be granted please.

There will still be need however for new toilets in the spring as Estimated for and I would be glad to have authority for the same as soon after April the first as possible.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, the Department will allow for the academic year 1937-38 the same amount as last year for purchase of mid-day meal supplies at the White Bears Indian Day School, viz: $50.00.

Sir:-

Referring to Page 9 of the Estimates 1927-28 concerning the White Bears Day School, I have to advise that the toilets are in a very bad condition and should be replaced at once. This matter was also dealt with Reference 113-1-5 of the 9th of December last.

The condition of the interior of the School is very bad and badly needs repainting at once.

The foundation repairs could at present be avoided by banking up for the coming winter. This total cost should not exceed $300.00.

Your obedient servant,

Eben A.W.R. McKenzie,

Ottawa, October 12, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, you may arrange for the erection of new toilets at the White Bears Indian Day School. It is understood that you will keep the cost as low as possible.

You may also have the foundation of the school banked.

Owing to lack of funds it is not possible to favorably consider the interior painting.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

I beg to attach a Requisition from Mr. McKenzie, Crooked Lakes Agency, for $6.15 worth of supplies for the mid-day meals, White Bear School.

In arriving at this figure, Mr. McKenzie has allowed 2½ cents a meal, then deducted the amount of biscuits supplied by the Department. This should, in the opinion of two of our experienced Day School teachers, supply a nourishing meal, and I would recommend that it be granted.

It will be noted that he is asking for 100 lbs. of onions and 100 lbs. of carrots. Onions and carrots were planted in the Community Garden at White Bear this season, but were destroyed by the grasshoppers and other pests, consequently will have to be purchased. With regard to the biscuits supplied by the Department, it is very doubtful, in my mind, whether on Reserves where we can secure meat, vegetables, etc., it is economical to supply these biscuits. A saving might be made by discontinuing the biscuits and increasing the amount of meat and vegetables. This is a matter I am taking up with our experienced teachers, and upon receipt of their replies I will submit a report.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: White Bear Day School.

I beg to advise that I am in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Mabel K. Waywell, teacher at the above school, drawing attention to the fact that at the opening of the next term they will have an enrollment of 39 pupils, and that their allowance for the mid-day meal is $50.00 or an expenditure of 25¢ a day for the 200 teaching days. She points out that this is not sufficient to give a nourishing lunch and asks that the amount be increased.

It is the opinion of all engaged in the field that a nourishing mid-day lunch is of the utmost importance. It is the only nourishing meal which many of our day school children receive. This particularly applies to White Bear Reserve, where the health conditions are probably the worst in the Province. I have no hesitation in stating that a good, nourishing mid-day meal would do more to build up these children and improve their health than double the amount of money spent in any other way. I would recommend that this allowance be increased to $75.00.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 18th instant with reference to the midday meal at the White Bear Indian day school.

In view of reports received that the Indians of this Reserve have been suffering from adverse conditions it has been decided to allow, during the academic year 1939-40, an amount of $75.00 for the purchase of midday meal supplies at the White Bear school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No. 113-1-5 of September 10th 1940, re the midday lunch at the White Bears Day School, would you kindly consider an increase of $25.00 in order to purchase flour, lard and baking powder; that the older girls might make baking powder biscuits, to take the place of the regular biscuits.

There are 34 pupils at this school coming from very poor Indian homes, the midday meal is often the best of the day for them. There is a kitchen at the school fairly well equipped, and the benefit from the food and the cooking lessons would mean a great deal to health and welfare of the children.

Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from W.J.D. Kerley, Indian Agent, with reference to the amount authorized for midday meal supplies at the White Bears School.

Until last year it was our custom to supply biscuits and allow an additional amount of $50.00 for the academic year. In 1939 the late Inspector Robertson strongly recommended increasing the amount to $75.00 plus biscuits.

Due to the reduction in our appropriation biscuits were not purchased this year but we have authorized an expenditure of $75.00. I am now in receipt of a letter from the Agent requesting that this be increased to $100.00 as he states there are 34 pupils attending the school and that they come from very poor homes.

It must be kept in mind by all officials that economies have to be effected in every possible way. Besides, at the majority of Indian day schools in Canada it has been the custom to only serve a midday lunch during the winter months. Apparently without any specific instructions to that effect the teacher in charge of the White Bears School serves a midday lunch throughout the entire academic year.

Are conditions on the White Bears Reserve as serious as the Indian Agent intimates? With the above in

Mr. M. Christianson,
Gen. Supt. of Indian Agencies,
Dominion Public Bldg.,
Scarth & Victoria,
Regina, Sask.
mind do you consider it necessary to serve a midday lunch on every school day? Do you advise increasing the amount to $100.00 as the Agent requests?

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 113-1-5 of the 22nd instent in connection with the request of Mr. Kerley, the Indian Agent at Broadview, that White Bear School be given $100.00 a year to supply a mid-day meal to the children there.

I happened to visit the school last week and I found a very competent teacher in charge in the person of Mrs. Mabel K. Waywell, who is full of energy and I would say is rendering splendid work in this institution. However, as the Provincial Superintendent of Schools was there a few days ahead of me, we will wait until we receive his report. In looking over the registration I found that there were 34 pupils on the roll and an average attendance for the year of approximately 30. For an Indian Day School this is outstanding.

One hundred dollars a year for the mid-day meal would be approximately $11.10 per month, or .55¢ per day. The Department must know that the White Bear Indians are a very poor lot. Tuberculosis and scrofula are rampant on this Reserve. The Indians have had seven crop failures in a row and this Fall is the first year for many that the Indians have had any returns at all. I am sure our Branch will realize that the children need something nourishing for a mid-day meal, coming from homes probably where they receive nothing but a little bannock and tea for breakfast. This .55¢ per day provides something to make soup with for the children, the vegetables used are grown there. I think if our Branch want to be reasonable they will agree with me that this .55¢ a day is not excessive.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo it has been decided to allow, for the academic year 1940-41, a total amount of $100.00 for the purchase of midday lunch supplies for the White Bear Indian Day School. This is the total amount that can be allowed and must not be over-expended.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Ever since starting this Indian school we have been laboring under a great disadvantage, owing partly to unsuitable textbooks. The books we are using are very good for pupils who are familiar with the English language. But most of the lessons in them are not suited for teaching a child to speak the English language. Such a book may do in an industrial school where the pupil hears nothing but English spoken. But it is very different in the day school where the pupil hears no English except from the teacher. We find the best way to teach English is by question and answer. And I have included a sample lesson which we find very useful in teaching them to speak English. We have the pupils commit the question and answers to memory. Then after reading the lesson we ask questions and have them answer and by varying the questions we get them to thoroughly understand what they have been reading. For instance we will ask the question, "What does the bear like for dinner?" Then after receiving the answer we will ask, "What do you like for dinner?"

Is there any such a book as published? And if not do you think you could recommend having such an one published. The lessons could be taken from the Ontario Readers with a supplement to each following the lesson.

I think if any Indian child had gone through the Ontario Second Reader so revised would have a very good knowledge of the Indian language.

Will you kindly let me hear from you on the subject.

Indian Affairs Ottawa

The White Bear.

Question: What did we read about in another lesson?
Answer: About the black bear.

1. What have we been reading in this lesson?
   A. About the white or polar bear

2. Where does the white bear live?
   A. He lives away in the far north

3. Do they have much winter there?
   A. Yes; there is nearly always snow on the ground

4. What kind of summers do they have there?
   A. The summer is very cold

5. What makes the summer so cold?
   A. There are always great pieces of ice floating in the sea

6. Is the bear afraid of the cold?
   A. No; he has a coat of fur to keep him warm

7. Can you tell me why he never slips on the ice?
   A. Because the soles of his feet are covered with long hair

8. Does he make any noise when he walks?
   A. No; he walks as softly as if on a pair of fur shoes

9. Why does he like to live near the sea?
   A. Because he likes to swim in the water

10. Can you give another reason?
    A. For there he finds plenty of fish and seals to eat

11. What does he like to have for dinner?
    A. He likes to catch a seal for his dinner

12. What does he try to find?
    A. He tries to find a place where the water is clear

13. Why does he do that?
    A. Because he knows the seals will come up there to breathe

14. When he finds such a place what does he do?
    A. He watches for the seals and keeps very quiet

15. When a seal comes up to breathe what does it generally do?
    A. It crawls out upon the ice and goes to sleep
2. What does the bear do then?
A. He creep softly along towards the seal
2. Does he make any noise in so doing?
A. No, the long hair on his feet enables him to walk noiselessly.
2. If the seal wakes up and looks around what does the bear do?
A. He falls down flat upon the ice and lies very still
2. What does the seal do then?
A. When he sees no one about he goes to sleep again
2. How does the bear act then?
A. He does the same thing over and over again until he gets close to the seal then he jumps on him and kills and eats him
2. Does he ever hunt anything else than seals?
A. Yes, he sometimes catches fish
2. How does he catch fish?
A. He jumps into the water after them and he is so quick that he often catches them before they can get away
2. When he can find neither seals or fish what does he do?
A. He goes to a place where the snow has melted and feeds on berries.
2. Yes, but if he can find no berries what does he eat?
A. He eats sea-weed which he can always find along the seashore.
2. Where does the black bear live in the winter?
A. He crawls into his den and there sleeps till the next spring.
2. Does the white bear do the same?
A. No; where the white bear lives there is winter nearly all the time.

(Sioux)

From April 1st to November 9th, 1909.

Date of inspection November 8th, 9th and 10th, 1909

17. The Parents who have children of school age inquired whether it was the intention of the Department to re-open the day school on this reserve. They would be glad to see this done, and spoke as though they would avail themselves of its benefits. I made a census of the school population and found that there are 8 boys and 3 girls, in all 11 children of school age on the reserve. These belong to seven families and their homes are situated that they could all conveniently attend a school centrally located. The school was closed some years ago on account of the removal of the Indians from the vicinity of the school to a more remote part of the reserve, the number of children of school age being then also quite small.

As an evidence of the results of former school work here I may say that during the inspection I had occasion to obtain the signatures of ten men of the band. Six of them signed their names in perfectly regular and legible hand. These are, of course, among the younger men; and they also speak English with a fair degree of correctness and fluency.

Respectfully submitted,

Prince Albert (sgnd) W. J. Chisholm

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 23rd inst., relative to the advisability of re-opening the day school on the Moose Woods reserve, I have the honour to report that I have no definite information later than that contained in paragraph 17 of my report on the inspection of this reserve dated Dec. 17th, 1909. The school population was at that time 11, and it may now be slightly larger as there were then a relatively large number of children just under school age.

The opening of a school here would involve considerable expense; but in my opinion it would be wisely incurred, provided there is a prospect of securing a suitable teacher, who would require to be a married man or woman. The Indians are located in such a way that it should be possible to maintain an average attendance close to the maximum. The parents of children of school age are still, I understand, anxious for the re-building and re-opening of the school.

Question of reopening Day Schools

14. An enumeration of the school population was made and there were found to be 10 boys and 5 girls; or including the family of Yellow Hawk, who are likely to be permanent residents, 11 boys and 6 girls, making 17 in all of school age. These are all so situated that they could attend a school centrally located; and this condition is not likely to be altered. The Indians, all of whom are anxious for the reopening of the school, express the opinion that these children would all attend regularly, barring cases of sickness. In most cases the children are learning a few words of English from their parents, and to count both in the Dakota language and in English. A day school with a well trained teacher in charge would do a valuable work here.
