10. The Indians have renewed their request for the re-opening of the day school, and are very urgent in the matter. They complain that some of their children are coming to be almost beyond the age for attendance at school and yet as they have never had a school to attend they are entirely without education. They have been asked repeatedly to send their children to the industrial or boarding schools; but they are strongly opposed to the idea, and say that they will never allow their children to leave home for the purpose of attending school. I have observed that about half the Indians of this Band over 21 years of age, or practically all between 21 and 40 years, are able to speak, read and write English, while those under 21 can speak but a few words and cannot read or write. This certainly is an unfortunate state of things.

There are at present 14 children of school age in the Band. Two of these are at Qu'Appelle at present, but it is understood that their father would bring them back promptly in case a school were opened here. They are not attending school at Qu'Appelle, but merely staying with a relative.

The total population, and the school population, have been rather steady for some years past; and they are so located on the reserve that all would be within three quarters of a mile from a school centrally situated.
It is impossible to predict with absolute certainty what the future of the Band may be; but to all present appearances a school would be useful and successful from the beginning, and with a prospect of its usefulness increasing.

Respectfully submitted,

(Sgd) W.J. Chisholm,
Insp.of Indian Agencies.

Dear Mr. Ghisholm,

We purpose giving up the appointment of the Dundurn circuit; Mrs. Sanderson and myself have been overtaxed. We are prepared to give our whole time to the work of "Moose Woods Reserve" providing satisfactory arrangements can be made.

We have been married seven years and we have never had a dwelling that is worthy of the name "Home." We even dread the severe months of winter on the "Reservation". We could not during the severe cold period sleep upstairs and to have beds downstairs would be constant confusion. We don't mind the inconvenience when the climate favours it. I would not mind bearing it alone, but when it comes to my wife and children having to bear it it is more than can be expected. If a house and school is built next year things will be much better.

We would be glad if you could arrange for us to have four months leave of absence, during which time we would visit our home in England, which has been well earned. Family ties have been broken. Three years ago I lost my Father, and Mother is now feeble. Mrs. Sanderson had a brother killed in the war; her parents had an accident at the same time and only escaped death, and are still suffering the consequences. So if you could do this we would appreciate it very much; and no doubt we would resume our work by April 1st 1916 with new life, and we would teach through the summer months.
Or, if you would permit, I would try and secure someone to take the work for Jan., Feb., Mar., and we would teach until the middle of December ----- and that person would have the use of our home there.

Believe me,

I am,

Yours very sincerely,

"R. H. Sanderson."

I have just returned from Dundurn where I interviewed Mr. Sanderson regarding this matter and beg to report as follows:

I find that Mr. Sanderson while taking charge of the school on the Reserve attended to three Methodist missions where he held services every Sunday. These services were held at Dundurn, Coate's School nine miles north-east of Dundurn, and Woodview School five miles northeast of Dundurn. In order to do this he apparently left the Reserve on Saturday morning and did not return until Monday noon, Mrs. Sanderson taking charge of the school in his absence. Owing to the fact that Mrs. Sanderson has not yet returned from the Old Country Mr. Sanderson apparently does not wish to do his own housekeeping on the Reserve.

I pointed out to Mr. Sanderson that the suggestion he made in his letter to the Department was an impossible one and it is quite evident that he made this suggestion with the idea of having an arrangement with the Department which would enable him to carry on his mission work. It is quite apparent, however, that the school work as far as he is concerned is a secondary consideration.

When at the Reserve on Friday last I called at the school and from what I observed I am satisfied so far as Mr. Hawke is concerned he has made considerable improvement since my previous visit. While his methods of teaching are not of the best yet I notice that the pupils are making some progress and the discipline is perfectly good. Mr. Hawke understood that he was to give place to Mr. Sanderson right away, but I advised him to continue teaching and in all probability the Department would ask him to continue school until summer vacation. This he was quite agreeable to do. Mr. Hawke, so far, has no farm operations to attend to so that he is at liberty to continue.

I would recommend that Mr. Hawke be asked to teach until summer vacation and in the mean time a teacher be found to take the place of Mr. Sanderson.

Inspector.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I sent Rev. Arthur Barner a copy of the letter which I wrote you on April 7th, with a statement of the situation as I understood it in connection with the School on the Moose Woods Reserve. He replies in part as follows:

"The statement you make to Mr. Russell Ferrier is true, as far as it goes, but I shall be glad if you will write to him again upon receipt of this, completing the statement.

It is as follows:

"When I visited this Reserve on the 31st of January last I found that the school had been closed since the 17th of November last, owing to the fact that Mr. Coveney could not get through so much deep snow every day. I proposed to the Indians that Mr. Charles Hawke (who had taught there previously) be engaged by Mr. Coveney as supply until he could again resume duties in the spring; Mr. Coveney to be recognized as in charge of the school. This was agreed to by all concerned. I reported my action to Rev.C.Endicott and to Rev.C.W.Brown of Saskatoon. They agreed to this as a temporary arrangement.

"I agree with Mr. Ferrier's judgment that the plan of supplying the school from Dundurn is impracticable and I so reported to Messrs. Endicott and Brown when I returned from the Reserve. They, however, wished to give the scheme a good try-out. On the other hand we are up against the difficulty of being absolutely unable to station a teacher there as there is no building in which to live. Mr.Hawke is a member of the Band and has his home on the Reserve. I would not be in favor of engaging him for any great length of time as teacher, though it is much better to have him in charge than it would be to close the school.

"I think the Department has treated us very generously as far as the finances for this year are concerned. I also think that Mr. Ferrier's suggestion of a man and wife there to take charge of the Reserve and the school is the ideal arrangement. Strange to say I received an application from a graduate of one of our Agricultural Colleges just this morning, who, I think, would fill such a place. I am corresponding with him and if I think him suitable I will send his name to Mr. Ferrier.

"Since I returned from Toronto I received word from Rev.C.W.Brown that Dundurn has entered the Union ranks and..."

"that as a consequence it will be impossible for the minister at that point to teach school at Moose Woods after the present year. All things work together for good."

Dear Dr. Manning:

I have yours of the 7th and 19th instant, referring to the White Cap Sioux Indian Day School on the Moose Wood reserve. I am still hopeful that funds will be provided this year for the erection of a combined school and teacher's residence. In the event of success in this connection, you will be asked to nominate a man and his wife for this reserve. The lady could do the teaching, at a salary say of $750 per annum plus whatever bonus is allowed by law. The man could act as lay missionary for the church and would receive from the Department a small stipend as overseer, a second remuneration as janitor and a third payment in case the services of a truant officer are required. A total of perhaps $350 per annum could be offered for these services, or a grand total for man and wife of $1250, which includes the present bonus.

If the Missionary Society could give say $350 a year to the man for services as missionary, there is no reason, with the new building as a home, why we could not engage the services of an excellent couple, who would put the Moose Wood reserve into a splendid condition. If at all possible, the man should have a knowledge of farming activities. I personally feel that this is a splendid opportunity to do real Christian and civilizing work, and a good couple would make their presence and worth felt throughout a community of 60 Indian people.

This information and these suggestions are confidential for the time being, and no overtures should be made in which it is promised that a new building is to be erected. I am sending to the Rev. Mr. Barner a copy of this letter, for his information.

The temporary arrangements with Mr. Charles Hawke, although not wholly satisfactory, are approved.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,

Reference to the last paragraph of your letter of the 10th of February, No. 109-11-1, re giving a mid-day meal to the children of the Moose Woods reserve day school.

I have the honour to report that I visited the school and made arrangements for the serving of the meal. This will be prepared by Mrs. Churchill who will be assisted by the older girls from the school. The meal will be served in the teachers residence.

I asked Mrs. Churchill to prepare a list of what she would require for the meal, the following is part of same.

| Item       | Quantity |
|------------|----------|
| Beef       | 20 lbs. per month |
| Lard       | .5 "      |
| Tea        | 2 "       |
| Rice       | 2 "       |
| Beans      | 6 "       |
| Oatmeal    | 10 "      |
| Sugar      | 10 "      |
| Soap       | 5 "       |
| Potatoes   | 1 Bu.     |
| Baking Powder | 1 lb. |

I recommend that the above articles be authorized. Fresh beef can be bought in Dundurn and brought out to the reserve on different occasions by Indians who go for their mail. The lard is to be used as butter.

Mrs. Churchill also asked for Cocoa, Corn starch, Tapioca, Evaporated apples, or prunes, or other dried fruit. I informed her that I did not supply these at other schools, and would not purchase same unless authorized by the Department. A flour bin is necessary for the school, and I recommend that one be purchased at a cost of about $4.00.

Mr. Churchill asked me whether the Department would supply fuel for his residence and the school room. Since he arrived on the reserve he has purchased wood and coal for his house. The Indians have as yet supplied the fuel for the school room free of charge. As Mrs. Churchill is to prepare the children's meal in her home, I think it only fair that we supply the fuel for this purpose at least, if not for heating the house throughout.
I wish to draw the Department's attention to the size of the teachers house. This is a two room cottage, 18x24 feet, the front room is used as a living room and bedroom, the rear part for a kitchen, dining room etc., as it is these rooms are crowded. I noticed Mrs Churchill's washing machine, and other things were left outside, these cannot be used inside in summer, in rain & snow. Other things such as storm sash, screen doors and windows when taken down must be stored away, and we have no room. I would suggest that an addition say 12 feet be built at the back of the building, all under the roof, this addition could be divided into two rooms, one to be used as a pantry and the other as a store room, wood shed or summer kitchen.

If the Department approves of the idea, I will prepare a list of material required and figure out the approximate cost of building same.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 395-11 dated July 7th, re the report made by Mr. A.R. Brown of the Normal School, Saskatoon, on the Moose Woods Indian School which he inspected, and asking me for my report on the matter.

In my opinion the children of this reserve are not different to other Indian children, and if the attendance and punctuality is good and fair, as I am told it is, I see no reason why the children cannot make as good progress here as in other schools.

As to it being difficult to hear the pupils read, there is no difference here, with other schools, and it simply rests with the teacher whether they mutter or shout their words. I have been at this school and remarked to the teachers that the pupils did not speak loud enough, that they did not stand properly with head up and face forward, that they held their readers in front of their faces. I have made them stand erect - look me in the face, and repeat till they spoke loudly words they had muttered.

There is no reason why children 8-10 or 12 years of age in standards 1-2 or 3 should not understand words they read, if these words have been explained to them.

As regards their being more or less hopeless as potential scholars, personally I should not class them as such, as they appear to me to be intelligent children whom I should judge possess sufficient efficiency and expressing power which could be developed advantageously.

The class room is a well-built well-light room with individual seats for all pupils. It is situate about the centre of the settlement, which is a row of homes built along the main road, the further of which is about one half mile from the school. Attendance and punctuality should be good if the teacher exercises proper vigilence and authority.

The parents are all favorable to, and ask for education for their children.

As regards Mr. Churchill, he has never impressed me as an Indian School teacher, and much less as a master.

When I first met him on the reserve he told me that he was there temporarily only, or until he could get some other position.

Yours truly,

W.M. Graham, Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, No. 109-11-1, re report of the teacher of the Whitecap Sioux School, re the condition of the supplies furnished for the preparation of the mid-day meal for the pupils of the school, and asking me for a report on same.

In reply I beg to say that the supplies shipped to the reserve for the destitute and the school are kept by Overseer Chas. R. Eagle in a small frame building at his home.

The bacon shipped some time ago being coarse, heavy, and fat, was kept in the shipping box & became mouldy and rather strong.

The rice and oatmeal are kept in tin cans, but it appears that mice got into same and left traces of their visit.

The balance on hand in the Overseers possession on the 30th ultimo was bacon, 153 lbs., rolled oats 56 lbs., rice 30 lbs. These will be issued to the destitute Indians during the winter months, and a fresh supply will be sent early in the year.

To say that these supplies are unfit for use is a matter on which opinions may differ, and the fact that they are kept and issued to the field nation by an Indian is, I have noticed, not altogether to her liking. I visited the reserve on the 12th instant, and told Mr. Churchill that he would ship him some rice and oatmeal which he will keep at his home. I will not ship any bacon at present as I have ordered some beef for the winter months. In the summer months I have made arrangements with the local butcher Mr. Taylor at Dundurn to supply the school with a few pounds of fresh beef each week; this is brought out by Mr. Churchill when he goes to town, or by an Indian who is given an order by Mr. Churchill to get same.

I trust that the above explanation will be satisfactory to the Department.

Sir:-

I have written to you on several occasions of late, regarding the Principals of our schools leaving the reserves without the knowledge of this office. The situation it has created makes it almost impossible for us to carry on, and as yet I have received no satisfaction whatever from you with regard to the matter.

I am in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at Duck Lake, in which he states as follows,-

"When I visited this reserve on the 11th inst. I found both Mr. & Mrs. Churchill were away and was informed by the Overseer, Chas. Eagle, that they had left the reserve during June, going to Winnipeg to attend some school or University. No application for leave of absence was received at this office."

It seems to me that no Government officer should leave the reserve without obtaining authority from those over him. Mrs. Churchill at least should not have left, and I am of the opinion that Mr. Churchill should have had leave of absence.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir,

I am in receipt of Department letter 109-11-1 of 8th instant with reference to principals of schools being absent from the Institutions in their charge without the Department or this office being aware of the fact.

Your letter referred to mentions only the case of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill of the Whitecap Sioux Day School but is apparently intended to cover the cases previously reported by me and referred to in my letter of 2nd instant to which it is a reply.

It is, of course, well understood that teachers employed and paid for ten teaching months would not consider it necessary to apply for leave during the time for which they receive no remuneration and in such cases it would be sufficient if they notified the Indian Agent, who would in turn inform this office, that they intended to be absent from the Reserve between certain dates. In the case under discussion the Indian Agent visited the Reserve expecting to see Mr. and Mrs. Churchill and had he known that they would not have been there he would have arranged his visit at a time to make sure of meeting them. It appears also that they left in June to attend College and it is just possible that they were away for some part of the time for which they drew salaries. If teachers can be absent without notice to the Department we will never know whether they are on duty or not. I think they should be required to give reasonable notice to the Indian Agent of their intention to leave the neighbourhood.

The Secretary,
Indian Department,
Ottawa, Ont.,
The more important phase of the matter however, has not been dealt with. The real trouble arises when principals of the residential schools are away at a time when it is important that they should be at home. Cases have occurred lately in which an Inspector of this Department has arrived at an institution of this kind expecting to transact important business, only to find that the principal is away. It is not necessary for me to point out that our Inspectors are much too busy to make long, expensive trips, only to be handicapped in this way when they arrive.

I do not think the Church Authorities under whose auspices these schools are operated would have the slightest objection to their appointees being required to arrange with the Department when they desire to be away. It is not my wish to approach the matter in an arbitrary or domineering spirit - I merely wish to secure their co-operation with a view to greater harmony and efficiency. The point I wish to make particularly clear is that a great deal of valuable time has been wasted and work has been delayed on account of my not knowing that this, that, or the other man was not on duty at a time when his presence was necessary. This can be avoided by the Department requiring that leave of absence be arranged for through this office and I trust this will be done.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of November 4th, No. 109-11-1 re Inspector Evert's report of his inspection of the Whitecap Sioux Day School:

Mr. Evert criticizes the teacher in his methods, lack of drill, etc., and then ends up by saying that the teacher was not in the school. He evidently intends to belittle the teacher and his work but in so doing places himself in a very undesirable position. The report being so contradictory condemns itself and needs no further consideration. I visited this school the latter part of November and found Mr. Churchill, the teacher, present in a well kept, clean class-room. His equipment and methods were up-to-date but the attendance was small. Mr. Churchill has a Second-Class Normal Certificate and is a graduate in Arts. In looking over the school register, I found that the average attendance in 1924 was 8.6 and for 1925 7.5 and the outlook is that it will not be any better for 1926. The entire population for the reserve is 67. Mrs. Churchill as nurse and field matron, is doing very good work on the reserve. She holds a Second-Class Normal Certificate.

If Mr. and Mrs. Churchill are desirous of doing this two-fold work of teaching and field matron work, they are well qualified for it and should have a larger number of people to whom they can render service. The expenditure of keeping two employees for such a small number of people can hardly be justified. The schoolhouse and teachers' residence are both very small buildings, yet large enough to accommodate all the children of school age and make a suitable home for one lady teacher. If the Department wishes to continue this work it should be under a lady teacher who would undertake to do the work of a field matron as well. A better arrangement would be to close the school and take the children to Brandon or Edmonton and this would be my recommendation.

All of which is respectfully submitted.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Reference the 26 lbs bacon which was reported as having been stolen in May. The following are the details:

Mr Chas Eagle, the Overseer, brought the bacon to the teachers residence in the forenoon. It was placed on top of an old dresser, in the drawers of which it was our custom to keep the meat after it had been cut up in convenient size pieces. On this particular occasion the meat was left on the dresser while we visited a neighbor off the reserve, between the hours of five and eight P.M. On our return we noticed that the meat was gone. Diligent search failed to locate it anywhere near the house, and as there were no traces of dogs having pulled the meat away, it was concluded that it had been stolen by some unknown party.

During our absence, while visiting, Miss Nora Littlecrow and her sister had been left in charge of the house. In the interval they had gone for a short walk with the baby, and it was perhaps then that the meat was taken, although the girls had not paid any particular attention to it and were not aware that it had been taken until we made mention of the fact. They had not noticed any dogs in the vicinity nor heard any noises near the house while they were inside.

Yours truly,

(signed) G.M. Churchill.

Dear Miss Hare,

I wish to thank you for your report for the month of September regarding your field work among the Indians of Moose Woods Reserve.

If you can teach these people to keep their homes, their children, and themselves reasonably clean, you will be accomplishing a great deal, and in this connection I enclose a departmental circular which may be of help to you. It was originally prepared for distribution in remote areas, but if you find that it can be suitably distributed to the Indians of your district, further copies will be sent on request. Other circulars pertaining to health regulations of the Department are being forwarded to you under separate cover, and from time to time literature will be sent you which we hope will be helpful in your work. A set of publications issued by the Child Welfare Council of Canada are also being forwarded and your name will be placed on the mailing list of the Canadian Anti-Tuberculosis Society to receive publications issued for laymen, and which I think you will find of service. While it is recognized that a number of the pamphlets being sent you are not suitable for use on the reserves, it is thought that you will find the information in them suitable to use in your talks with the Indian women.

While your September report is quite satisfactory, I would suggest that you might find it convenient to divide your monthly report into headings such as:

(a) House to house visiting,
(b) Sick calls,
(c) Child welfare,
(d) Classes or Mothers' Meetings,
(e) General remarks and recommendations.

Your obedient servant,

Since my last visit to this school Miss H. J. Hare has been appointed teacher. She holds her Second Class Professional, and has had 17 years teaching experience.

The children are very backward in their work and little, if any, progress is noticeable. Miss Hare has only been in charge since September, but is winning the confidence of the pupils and I expect she will do good work. The parents are very indifferent to education and consequently the children receive no encouragement from home. Furthermore, the parents all speak the Indian tongue and English only comes to the children during the few hours at school.

The school building and teacher's residence are both badly in need of painting. It is hoped to have this work carried out during the coming year if funds are obtainable.

Sir:

I beg to forward, herewith, Provincial School Inspector Everts' report of an inspection of Moose Wood Indian Day School in the Duck Lake Agency.

I was present in the class room while the Inspector was making his inspection. It will be noted by his report that the class standing in this school is away below what should be expected. I am quite in accord with him in his remarks in connection with conditions at this school and in my opinion it is not, as the teacher states, through lack of intelligence on the part of the children that this condition exists. They appear to me to be equal in intelligence to other children and I feel that a teacher who has belief in the possibility of educating the Indian children could do a great deal with them.

The teacher stated that if we knew the parents that these children sprang from we could understand their low state of intelligence. I made it a point to visit the parents and talked with them and found them to be bright and intelligent men, so that excuse does not carry any weight with me.

Comparison between the class room standing in this school and other Indian Day Schools where conditions are similar satisfies me that there is something wrong with the management. It is, in my opinion, very necessary that a teacher of Indian children or, I expect the same applies to any children, should be sympathetic and should have a belief that she can accomplish something. When a person starts out as apparently the teacher here has, with the belief that the Indian child is not capable of absorbing knowledge, I do not think that we can hope for much progress.

I am quite in accord with the inspector when he suggests that a change should take place at this school.

Your obedient servant,

W. Murison, Inspector,
Saskatchewan Inspectorate.

Rev. Sir:

The Department has received the report of the Public School Inspector on his recent inspection of the Whitecap Sioux (Voose Woods) Indian Day School. The Inspector states that the management of the school, under Miss Helena J. Hare, is most inefficient. Miss Hare has made very little success in the work. For your information, I quote from the Inspector's report, as follows:

"The management of the school is not considered at all efficient. If Indian children elsewhere can reach the requirements of the Saskatchewan curriculum, there should be no good reason why the same standard cannot be attained here. But the teacher does not seem to think this possible, does not believe in the ability of the children to reach the standing obtained elsewhere and does not seem to have confidence in herself to bring about these results. Her attitude is altogether antagonistic to suggestions."

Mr. Inspector Murison, who was present at the inspection, states that the class standing is way below what should be expected. He states that "comparison between the class standing in this school and other Indian day schools where conditions are similar satisfies me that there is something wrong with the management. When a person starts out, as apparently the teacher here has, with the belief that the Indian child is not capable of absorbing knowledge, I do not think that we can hope for much progress." He further states that he is entirely in accord with the Inspector when he recommends that a change in teacher should take place at this school.

I would request that Miss Hare's services be dispensed with, and that your Board nominate a qualified teacher for this school to replace Miss Hare, the duties of the new teacher to begin on or about September 1st, next.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR H. A. EVERTS ON HIS VISIT TO THE MOOSE WOODS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

DATE OF INSPECTION - Oct. 24/34.

SUCCESS - Rather mediocre, in fact I should not term her experience in this school a success in any appreciable measure. The pupils show very slow progress, even allowing for the fact that they might not be expected to progress as rapidly as children of white parents.

The routine work of the school could be arranged on a much more intensive basis, the children could receive much more encouragement to speak out clearly and to exert themselves mentally.

One is forced to ask the question if the teacher is not "marking time" to some extent.

It is felt that a younger teacher, with plenty of energy, with outstanding teaching ability and with improved organization could do much better.

Pupils attend quite regularly and no complaint was made regarding their punctuality.

This makes the matter of their progress in school a vital one. They do not show the progress that might be expected. In fact I have not been at all satisfied with this phase of the examination of the school. I am informed that on other reserves the pupils cover the same work as is prescribed for other children and attain suitable standing in their work.

It cannot be successfully maintained that the pupils are shy in the presence of strangers, because I taught a demonstration lesson on the "direct method" of teaching English, and had decidedly good results.

It is quite evident that, given an aggressive, sympathetic and enthusiastic teacher of ability, marked improvement in the standing of the pupils would be evident within a reasonable length of time. At the present rate of progress the pupils will not reach the standing that it considered normal for Grade IV pupils before they reach the age of 15 years, when most of them will discontinue school, with a very meagre equipment for the activities of adult life.
Ottawa, December 1, 1934.

"I am of the opinion that it would be in the interests of all concerned if Miss Hare were transferred to some other point. I believe a change of environment would not only be beneficial to her, but would be a relief to both myself and the Indian Agent. I do not think it is a good thing to leave a woman too long in an isolated place like Moose Woods where there are no other associations at a reasonable distance other than that of Indians."

Ottawa, June 22nd, 1926.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Church authorities have nominated the services of Mrs. Louise Fakeley as teacher of the Whitescap Sioux (Moose Woods) Indian Day School, to begin duties when this school reopens after the summer holidays, on or about September 1st, next. Mrs. Fakeley has had previous experience as a teacher in Indian schools in British Columbia. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $90 per teaching month, and besides her duties in the classroom she will also do a certain amount of field matron work on the Reserve.

I shall be pleased if you will give Mrs. Fakeley every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. P. Schmidt, Esq.,

Ottawa, August 15th, 1929.

Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a return for the quarter ended June 30th, last, for the Whitecap Sioux Indian Day School, which was taught by Mrs. A. L. Fakeley.

The school was only open for twelve (12) days during the quarter owing to the fact that the teacher was absent through illness from April 20th to May 24th, while, on May 28th, the school was closed by order of the medical officer owing to an outbreak of whooping cough.

In view of the fact that the school was only open for twelve (12) days during the quarter, the Department is doubtful as to what amount should be allowed as salary. You are aware of what the Missionary Society has allowed Mrs. Fakeley and I would appreciate your advising me what amount you consider would be fair for us to pay in order to reimburse you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
